Notes
1 1. 10 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5.
1-8-2: REAL ESTATE INTEREST DISCLOSURE:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein:
AGENT: A person authorized to act for another person or corporation.
APPLICANT: One who applies for any benefits on behalf of himself or some other
entity.
BENEFICIAL INTEREST: Any interest in a land trust.
BENEFICIARY: Any person, corporation or other entity having a beneficial
interest in a land trust.
CORPORATION: A body of persons authorized by law to act together as a single
person and, for the purpose of this section, includes any association, joint
stock company, syndicate or partnership.
LAND TRUST: An express agreement whereby the legal and equitable title to real
estate is held by a trustee for the benefit of beneficiaries who have the
exclusive right to manage and control said real estate.
LESSEE: One who has an interest in real estate by virtue of a lease.
NOMINEE: One designated to act for another, with limited authority.
OPTION HOLDER: One having the right to purchase real estate upon compliance
with conditions named in a contract.
STOCKHOLDER: One owning certificates of stock in a corporation or membership in
an association, joint stock company, syndicate or partnership.
   B.   Applications:
      1.   Signature Of Applicant: Any application to the village board of
trustees or village boards and commissions for authorization, benefit, license,
permit, variation, zoning amendment or planned unit development relating to
real estate shall be signed by the owner, lessee, option holder, agent or
nominee of either.
      2.   Required Information:
         a.   If the application is made by a person other than the fee owner,
it shall be accompanied by an affidavit of the owner that the person signing
the application has authority to make the application, and the application
shall disclose the full names, addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant
and owner.
         b.   If the applicant or the owner is a corporation, the application
shall disclose the names and addresses of the officers, directors, registered
agent and those shareholders or members owning in excess of five percent (5%)
of the outstanding stock or interest in the corporation.
         c.   If the applicant is a trustee, the full name, address, telephone
number and the extent of the interest of each beneficiary must be disclosed.
         d.   If the applicant is a beneficiary, nominee or option holder, the
application must disclose the names, addresses and telephone numbers of those
persons or entities for whom he is acting, and if it is a corporation, the
provisions of subsection B2b of this section shall be complied with. (Ord. 449,
5-9-1974)
   C.   False Statements: After a statement is determined to be falsified,
missing or incorrect, a written notice of the omission or falsification shall
be sent to the applicant; each day that elapses until the date the required
information is furnished or corrected shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 449, 5-9-1974; amd. 1994 Code)
1-8-3: CORPORATE SEAL:
The corporate seal of the village shall be in such form as prescribed by the
village president and board of trustees. (1994 Code)
1-8-4: RETURNED CHECKS:
Any person who pays any bill, fine, charge or fee to the village with any check
or draft that is subsequently returned unpaid to the village because of
insufficient funds or because of a stop order on such check or draft shall be
liable to the village for the greater of the bank charge incurred by the
village, plus the administrative costs of collecting the money, or thirty
dollars ($30.00) for each and every check so returned. Such service charges
shall be paid within seven (7) days of notification, in cash or by money order
or certified check before the bill, fine, charge or fee for which such check
was tendered shall be considered paid. Should two (2) such checks or drafts be
returned within a one year period, no further payments shall be accepted from
such person except in the form of cash, certified check, cashier's check or
money order for a period of six (6) months from the date of the return of the
second check or draft. (Ord. 2004-12-51, 12-2-2004)
1-8-5: COLLECTION FEES:
Any person who is indebted to the village of Winfield for any amount past due
and whose account has been transferred to any agency for the purpose of
recuperating the full amount of the debt, shall be responsible to pay the fees,
costs, fines and/or penalties associated with the debt collection agency and
process in addition to the debt amount due to the village of Winfield. (Ord.
2015-05-15, 5-7-2015)
CHAPTER 9
ETHICS
SECTION:
1-9-1: Application
1-9-2: Conflict Of Interest
1-9-3: Confidentiality
1-9-4: Use Of Government Resources
1-9-5: Scope Of Office
1-9-6: Authority
1-9-7: Open Government
1-9-8: Village Board Interactions With Developers
1-9-1: APPLICATION:
This code of ethics shall apply to all elected officials of the village and to
all persons appointed by the board of trustees or by the president to any
position, board or commission ("village officials"). The ethical standards,
considerations, and rules of conduct shall apply and be observed during the
term of office or service of the village official with the village. (Ord. 97-6-
28, 6-17-1997)
1-9-2: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
   A.   Definition: Except as otherwise provided by 50 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 105/1 et seq., as now existing or hereafter amended, the term
"conflict of interest" shall mean:
      1.   Engaging in any business or transaction or having a financial or
personal interest that is incompatible with the proper discharge of official
duties in the public interest; or
      2.   Engaging in or accepting private employment or rendering service for
private interest when such employment or service is incompatible with proper
discharge of official duties or would tend to impair independence of judgment;
or
      3.   Soliciting or accepting any valuable gift, favor or service or
benefit as inducement for or compensation for official act or action; or
      4.   Granting, performing or making available any special favor,
advantage, consideration or treatment to any person beyond that which is
available to all residents of the village.
   B.   Prohibited: No village official shall knowingly engage in any activity
that would be deemed a conflict of interest hereunder during the village
official's term of office or service.
   C.   Disclosures: In addition to the statement of economic interest filed by
the village official, every village official shall disclose any personal
business interest related to proposed village legislation or action, and the
village official shall disclose the nature and extent of such interest prior to
discussion, expressing an opinion, making a recommendation or taking action.
(Ord. 97-6-28, 6-17-1997)
1-9-3: CONFIDENTIALITY:
   A.   No village official shall disclose information which:
      1.   Is or may be the subject of an official act or action of the village
without proper authorization.
      2.   Can be kept confidential under the terms of the Illinois freedom of
information act 1 .
      3.   Is confidential under the personnel record review act 2  which
provides that an employer or former employer shall not divulge a disciplinary
report, letter of reprimand, or other disciplinary action to a third party, to
a party who is not a part of the employer's organization, or to a party who is
not a part of a labor organization representing the employee, without written
notice as provided in the law.
      4.   Release of minutes of executive sessions prior to approval of
minutes for public release. (Ord. 2006-8-35, 8-17-2006)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq., as now existing or hereafter amended.
2 2. 820 ILCS 40/7 et seq., as now existing or hereafter amended.
1-9-4: USE OF GOVERNMENT RESOURCES:
No village official shall use or allow the use of government service, property
or funds for private purposes or for purposes other than those authorized or
permitted except as otherwise generally available to the public. (Ord. 97-6-28,
6-17-1997)
1-9-5: SCOPE OF OFFICE:
Every village official shall refrain from making any private promise, the
performance of which would require acting beyond the proper scope of said
village official's duties, and shall refrain from acting in a manner which
would compromise the integrity of public office. (Ord. 97-6-28, 6-17-1997)
1-9-6: AUTHORITY:
No village official shall knowingly or negligently mislead or allow others to
mislead the public or other government officials. No village official shall
intentionally act outside the scope of authority in representing the village
official's office or allow a perception that the village official is acting on
behalf of the village when in fact he/she is not. (Ord. 97-6-28, 6-17-1997)
1-9-7: OPEN GOVERNMENT:
Village officials shall act in accordance with the spirit and intent of the
open meetings act 1 , and deliberations of the village board and its related
boards, committees, commissions or advisory bodies shall be conducted openly
except where public interest or personal rights may be adversely affected.
(Ord. 97-6-28, 6-17-1997)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq., as now existing or hereafter amended.
1-9-8: VILLAGE BOARD INTERACTIONS WITH DEVELOPERS:
   A.   For the purposes of this section, the term "developer" shall be defined
as someone who makes a business out of turning vacant, or underused, or
existing developed parcels of land into new or rehabilitated residential,
business, commercial or industrial projects that is acting in their own behalf
or as an agent for any landowner or equitable owner, for whom subdivision or
land development plans are being or have been made. This definition shall not
include an owner wishing to develop or redevelop a home on a single site.
   B.   These guidelines shall be followed by members of the village board,
excepting the village president, when any such person is directly contacted in
his/her capacity as an officer of the village, and not in the conduct of his/
her private business capacity, by a developer or their agent who is proposing a
development or redevelopment within the village of Winfield:
      1.   If the formal petition or application review process has not yet
been initiated:
         a.   The contacted village board member should refer the developer to
the appropriate village staff member who handles proposals in regard to
development or redevelopment in the community. In this manner the developer
will be provided the most accurate information and the entire governing body
can be kept apprised of developer interactions.
         b.   The contacted village board member shall advise the developer of
the village's ethics ordinance concerning interactions with developers and
encourage the developer to directly contact village community development staff
for professional assistance.
         c.   In the event that a meeting has been arranged to facilitate the
contact with the developer, an appropriate member of the village staff shall be
present at said meeting.
      2.   Once the formal petition or application review process has begun:
         a.   The contacted village board member shall inform the developer
that as the formal petition or application review process has begun, all
contacts with the developer and the contacted individual will be limited to
contacts at meetings and review sessions, which are a part of the formal
petition or application review process provided for in the village ordinances.
         b.   Community development staff will assist the developer with
questions and preparation for a concept presentation to the village board,
while respecting the developer's need for discretion.
      3.   In no instance before or after the review process has begun shall a
trustee without authorization of the village board make representations on
behalf of the village, attempt to explain village code development
requirements, attempt to negotiate terms of any development agreement, nor
accept or provide any development related documents. Each of these activities
identifies a situation in which village staff should be involved with the
knowledge of the full board.
      4.   It is further recognized that board members should not attempt to
assert undue influence on the development process, which impacts the village as
a whole, and that developments are best treated as Winfield projects, not
individual board member projects. (Ord. 2013-07-22, 7-18-2013)
CHAPTER 10
STATE ETHICS REGULATIONS
SECTION:
1-10-1: Definitions
1-10-2: Prohibited Political Activities
1-10-3: Gift Ban
1-10-4: Ethics Advisor
1-10-5: Ethics Commission
1-10-6: Complaints/Hearings
1-10-7: Conflicts
1-10-8: Penalties
1-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings ascribed to them herein:
CAMPAIGN FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE: Any activity in furtherance of an effort to
influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual
to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political
organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice
presidential electors, but does not include activities: a) relating to the
support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action,
b) relating to collective bargaining, or c) that are otherwise in furtherance
of the person's official duties.
CANDIDATE: A person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination
or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy
in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a
regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the election code 1 .
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section
3 of the Illinois public labor relations act 2 .
COMPENSATED TIME: With respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited
to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as
a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this chapter, does
not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time,
compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence.
With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, "compensated
time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the
control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is
executing his or her official duties, regardless of location.
COMPENSATORY TIME OFF: Authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee
to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work
time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment.
CONTRIBUTION: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of
the election code 3 .
EMPLOYEE: A person employed by the village of Winfield, whether on a full time
or part time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the
direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how
the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor.
EMPLOYER: The village of Winfield.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or
other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not
limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements
related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of
an officer or employee.
LEAVE OF ABSENCE: Any period during which an employee does not receive: a)
compensation for employment, b) service credit toward pension benefits, and c)
health insurance benefits paid for by the employer.
OFFICER: A person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by
statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for
service in his or her official capacity.
POLITICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity in support of or in connection with any
campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not
include activities: a) relating to the support or opposition of any executive,
legislative, or administrative action, b) relating to collective bargaining, or
c) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
POLITICAL ORGANIZATION: A party, committee, association, fund, or other
organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement
of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under
section 9-3 of the election code 4 , but only with regard to those activities
that require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk.
PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITY: A. Preparing for, organizing, or participating
in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other
political event.
   B.   Soliciting contributions, including, but not limited to, the purchase
of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political
fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event.
   C.   Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or
report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution.
   D.   Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   E.   Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in
an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign
for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political
purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   F.   Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political
organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   G.   Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a
political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in
an effort to get voters to the polls.
   H.   Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or
filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or
against any referendum question.
   I.   Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in
that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office.
   J.   Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires.
   K.   Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign
literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any
candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
   L.   Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   M.   Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against
any referendum question.
   N.   Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party
convention.
   O.   Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any
election.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
   A.   Is seeking official action: 1) by an officer or 2) by an employee, or
by the officer or another employee directing that employee;
   B.   Does business or seeks to do business: 1) with the officer or 2) with
an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee;
   C.   Conducts activities regulated: 1) by the officer or 2) by an employee,
or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or
   D.   Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or
nonperformance of the official duties of the officer or employee. (Ord. 2004-5-
15, 5-6-2004)
 
Notes
1 1. 10 ILCS 5/1-3.
2 2. 5 ILCS 315/3.
3 1. 10 ILCS 5/9-1.4.
4 2. 10 ILCS 5/9-3.
1-10-2: PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES:
   A.   No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited
political activity during any "compensated time", as defined herein. No officer
or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the village in
connection with any prohibited political activity.
   B.   At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any
other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 1) as
part of that officer's or employee's duties, 2) as a condition of employment,
or 3) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal
time off).
   C.   No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in
any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee
being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a
salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or
otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation
or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited
political activity.
   D.   Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for
an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or
activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis
which are not prohibited by this chapter.
   E.   No person either: 1) in a position that is subject to recognized merit
principles of public employment or 2) in a position the salary for which is
paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal
standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant in
aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely
because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a
political party, or of a political organization or club. (Ord. 2004-5-15, 5-6-
2004)
1-10-3: GIFT BAN:
   A.   Gifts Prohibited: Except as permitted by this chapter, no officer or
employee, and no spouse of or immediate family member living with any officer
or employee (collectively referred to herein as "recipients"), shall
intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any "prohibited source", as
defined herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law or ordinance. No
prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this
section.
   B.   Exceptions: Subsection A of this section is not applicable to the
following:
      1.   Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same
conditions as for the general public.
      2.   Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or
member, pays the fair market value.
      3.   Any: a) contribution that is lawfully made under the election code
or b) activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political
organization or candidate.
      4.   Educational materials and missions.
      5.   Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business.
      6.   A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the
individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt,
great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife,
grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-
law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather,
stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half
sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the
individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee.
      7.   Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal
friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the
circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position or
employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and
not because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is
provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the
circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as: a) the history of the
relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the
gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between those individuals; b)
whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the
gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or business
reimbursement for the gift; and c) whether to the actual knowledge of the
recipient the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same
or similar gifts to other officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate
family members.
      8.   Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy five dollars ($75.00) per
person in value on a single calendar day; provided that the food or
refreshments are: a) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or
prepared or b) catered. For the purposes of this section, "catered" means food
or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any
means.
      9.   Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation, and other benefits
resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities
that are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if
the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position
or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to
others in similar circumstances.
      10.   Intragovernmental and intergovernmental gifts. For the purpose of
this chapter, "intragovernmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or
employee from another officer or employee, and "intergovernmental gift" means
any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of another
governmental entity.
      11.   Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death.
      12.   Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any
calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars
($100.00).
Each of the exceptions listed in this section is mutually exclusive and
independent of every other.
   C.   Disposition Of Gifts: An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an
immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate
this chapter if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift
from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to
its value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under
section 501(c)(3) of the internal revenue code of 1986, as now or hereafter
amended, renumbered, or succeeded. (Ord. 2004-5-15, 5-6-2004)
1-10-4: ETHICS ADVISOR:
   A.   The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees, shall designate an ethics advisor for the village. The duties of the
ethics advisor may be delegated to an officer or employee of the village unless
the position has been created as an office by the village.
   B.   The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees
of the village concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the
provisions of this chapter and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall
perform such other duties as may be delegated by the board of trustees. (Ord.
2004-5-15, 5-6-2004)
1-10-5: ETHICS COMMISSION:
   A.   There is hereby created a commission to be known as the ethics
commission of the village of Winfield. The commission shall be comprised of the
village president, the village clerk and the most senior trustee. In the event
of a conflict of interest, the remaining trustees, in order of seniority, shall
serve as alternate commissioners.
   B.   The commission shall have the following powers and duties:
      1.   To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its
duties and the exercise of its powers.
      2.   Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to
investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for
disciplinary actions, impose fines in accordance with section
1-10-6 of this chapter and refer violations of section
1-10-2 or
1-10-3 of this chapter to the village prosecutor for prosecution. The
commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a written complaint
alleging a violation of this chapter and not upon its own prerogative.
      3.   To receive information from the public pertaining to its
investigations and to require additional information and documents from persons
who may have violated the provisions of this chapter.
      4.   To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production
of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all
officers and employees of the village to cooperate with the commission during
the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate with requests
by the commission shall constitute grounds for discipline or discharge.
      5.   The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters
clearly within the purview of this chapter. (Ord. 2004-5-15, 5-6-2004)
1-10-6: COMPLAINTS/HEARINGS:
   A.   Complaints alleging a violation of this chapter shall be filed with the
ethics commission.
   B.   Within three (3) business days after the receipt of a complaint, the
commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to
the respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of
the complaint. The commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt
requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant
within three (3) business days after receipt by the commission. The notices to
the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time,
and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the complaint and to
establish whether probable cause exists to proceed.
   C.   Upon not less than forty eight (48) hours' public notice, the
commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the
complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this chapter, to
determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by
the complainant, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the
extent authorized by the open meetings act. The commission shall issue notice
to the complainant and the respondent of the commission's ruling on the
sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to proceed
within seven (7) business days after receiving the complaint.
   D.   If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section
1-10-3 of this chapter and there is a determination of probable cause, then the
commission's notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled
within four (4) weeks after the receipt of the complaint. Alternatively, the
commission may elect to notify in writing the village prosecutor and request
that the complaint be adjudicated judicially. If the complaint is deemed not
sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable
cause, then the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt
requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint,
and that notice shall be made public.
   E.   If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section
1-10-2 of this chapter, then the commission shall notify in writing the village
prosecutor and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional
documents in the custody of the commission concerning the alleged violation.
   F.   On the scheduled date and upon at least forty eight (48) hours' public
notice of the meeting, the commission shall conduct a hearing on the complaint
and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence.
The hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized by the open meetings
act.
   G.   Within thirty (30) days after the date the hearing or any recessed
hearing is concluded, the commission shall either: 1) dismiss the complaint or
2) issue a recommendation for discipline to the alleged violator and to the
officer having authority to discipline the officer or employee, or impose a
fine upon the violator, or both. The particular findings in the case, any
recommendation for discipline, and any fine imposed shall be a matter of public
information.
   H.   If the hearing was closed to the public, the respondent may file a
written demand for a public hearing on the complaint within seven (7) business
days after the issuance of the recommendation for discipline or imposition of a
fine, or both. The filing of the demand shall stay the enforcement of the
recommendation or fine. Within fourteen (14) days after receiving the demand,
the commission shall conduct a public hearing on the complaint upon at least
forty eight (48) hours' public notice of the hearing and allow both parties the
opportunity to present testimony and evidence. Within seven (7) days
thereafter, the commission shall publicly issue a final recommendation to the
alleged violator and to the officer having authority to discipline the officer
or employee or impose a fine upon the violator, or both.
   I.   If a complaint is filed during the sixty (60) days preceding the date
of any election at which the respondent is a candidate, the commission shall
render its decision as required under subsection G of this section within seven
(7) days after the complaint is filed, and during the seven (7) days preceding
that election, the commission shall render such decision before the date of
that election, if possible.
   J.   The commission may fine any person who intentionally violates any
provision of section
1-10-3 of this chapter in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars
($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The commission
may fine any person who knowingly files a frivolous complaint alleging a
violation of this chapter in an amount of not less than one thousand one
dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The
commission may recommend any appropriate discipline up to and including
discharge.
   K.   A complaint alleging the violation of this chapter must be filed within
one year after the alleged violation. (Ord. 2004-5-15, 5-6-2004)
1-10-7: CONFLICTS:
Notwithstanding any policy, resolution, ordinance or portion of this Code to
the contrary, the provisions of this chapter shall prevail. (Ord. 2004-5-15, 5-
6-2004)
1-10-8: PENALTIES:
   A.   A person who intentionally violates any provision of this chapter may
be fined as provided in section
13-1-4 of this Code.
   B.   In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether
criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any
provision of section
1-10-2 or
1-10-3 of this chapter is subject to discipline or discharge. (Ord. 2019-02-01,
2-7-2019)

POLICY ON USE OF VILLAGE LOGO

1-11-2: Use Regulations
1-11-3: Penalty
1-11-1: LOGO ESTABLISHED:
The official Village of Winfield logo is identified below:
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/e69e56974fd8eb3967f8b4473ce72c7a644bafb1/

(Ord. 2006-6-27, 6-15-2006; amd. Ord. 2023-06-11, 6-11-2023)
1-11-2: USE REGULATIONS:
   A.   The official Village logo or part thereof may be reproduced only from
the approved reproduction proofs which may be obtained from the Village Hall.
   B.   The official Village logo or part thereof must be reproduced
photographically, except for some possible uses such as the flag, shoulder
patches, etc. for all printed materials; no handdrawn reproductions may be
used. If not reproduced photographically, the use must be approved by the
Village President and Board of Trustees.
   C.   The official Village logo or part thereof is copyrighted and registered
as a trademark. As such, it may be used only with the consent of the Village
President and Board of Trustees of Winfield, Illinois. Whenever the official
Village logo is reproduced in printed form, it must be accompanied by the
trademark symbol.
   D.   The official Village logo or part thereof may not be superimposed upon
or be tangent to any other symbol, nor may any other symbol be superimposed
upon or be tangent to the official Village logo.
   E.   Variations of the provisions of this policy or use of the Village logo
in any manner not covered in this policy or variations in form, color or
presentation of the Village logo not provided for in this policy must be
approved by the Village President and Board of Trustees. Applications for use
of the Village symbol whether in its official form or any other form should be
directed to the Village Manager. (Ord. 2006-6-27, 6-15-2006; amd. Ord. 2023-06-
11, 6-11-2023)
1-11-3: PENALTY:
Any person or organization convicted of violating this chapter shall be
punished as provided in section
13-1-4 of this Code. (Ord. 2019-02-01, 2-7-2019)
CHAPTER 12
ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS
SECTION:
1-12-1: Rules Statement
1-12-2: Participation
1-12-3: Voting Procedures
1-12-4: Adequate Equipment Required
1-12-5: Minutes
1-12-6: Rights Of Remote Member
1-12-1: RULES STATEMENT:
It is the decision of the village of Winfield that any member of the village
board, committees, boards and commissions established by authority of the
village of Winfield may attend any open or closed meeting of the village board,
committees, boards and commissions via electronic means (such as by telephone,
video or internet connection) provided that such attendance is in compliance
with these rules and any applicable laws. (Ord. 2009-07-21, 7-2-2009)
1-12-2: PARTICIPATION:
A member of the village board and committees, boards and commissions
established by authority of the village of Winfield may attend a meeting
electronically if the member meets the following conditions: A quorum is
physically present throughout the meeting; and a majority of the members of the
village board or committee, board and commission votes to approve the
electronic attendance at the meeting.
   A.   The member should notify the village clerk or board, commission or
committee secretary at least four (4) hours before the meeting, unless
impractical, so that necessary communications equipment can be arranged.
Inability to make the necessary technical arrangements will result in denial of
a request for electronic attendance.
   B.   The member must assert one of the following three (3) reasons why he or
she is unable to physically attend the meeting:
      1.   The member cannot attend because of personal illness or disability;
or
      2.   The member cannot attend because of employment purposes; or
      3.   The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency.
   C.   The village clerk or secretary, after receiving the electronic
attendance request, shall inform the village board or members of the other
boards, commissions or committees of the request for electronic attendance.
   D.   The member seeking participation shall be available on the telephone or
other communication device not less than five (5) minutes prior to the meeting.
   E.   Any costs associated with the member's participation shall be borne
solely by the member and not the village. (Ord. 2009-07-21, 7-2-2009)
1-12-3: VOTING PROCEDURES:
After a roll call establishing that a quorum is physically present, the village
president or chairperson shall call for a motion that a member may be permitted
to attend the meeting electronically after specifying the reason entitling the
absent member to attend electronically. The motion must be approved by a vote
of a majority of the members present of the applicable village board, committee
or commission. (Ord. 2009-07-21, 7-2-2009)
1-12-4: ADEQUATE EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
The member participating electronically and other members of the board,
committee or commission must be able to communicate effectively, and members of
the audience must be able to hear all communications at the meeting site.
Before allowing electronic attendance at any meeting, the village of Winfield
shall provide equipment adequate to accomplish this objective at the meeting
site. (Ord. 2009-07-21, 7-2-2009)
1-12-5: MINUTES:
Any member attending electronically shall be considered an off site attendee
and counted as present electronically for that meeting. The meeting minutes
shall also reflect and state specifically whether each member is physically
present or present by electronic means. (Ord. 2009-07-21, 7-2-2009)
1-12-6: RIGHTS OF REMOTE MEMBER:
A member permitted to attend electronically will be able to express his or her
comments during the meeting and participate in the same capacity as those
members physically present, subject to all general meeting guidelines and
procedures previously adopted and adhered to. The member attending
electronically shall be heard, considered, and counted as to any vote taken.
Accordingly, the name of any member attending electronically shall be called
during any vote taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded by the village
clerk or secretary and placed in the minutes for the corresponding meeting. A
member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in the case
of any member, provided the member attending electronically shall announce his
or her leaving and returning. (Ord. 2009-07-21, 7-2-2009)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
2-1-1: Board Established; Members
2-1-2: Powers And Duties
2-1-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS:
There is hereby established the board of local improvements for the village,
which shall consist of the village president and all of the members of the
board of trustees. (Ord. 340, 6-10-1966)
2-1-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of local improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties
assigned to it by statute or ordinance. (Ord. 340, 6-10-1966)
CHAPTER 2
PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-2-1: Creation Of Plan Commission
2-2-2: Appointment; Membership; Compensation
2-2-3: Terms Of Office; Vacancies; Removals
2-2-4: Rules Of Procedure
2-2-5: Powers
2-2-6: Official Comprehensive Plan
2-2-7: Public Art Mural Program
2-2-7-1: Establishment
2-2-7-2: Purpose
2-2-7-3: Definitions
2-2-7-4: Program Administration
2-2-7-5: Eligibility
2-2-7-6: Application Requirements
2-2-7-7: Standards For Approval
2-2-7-8: Installation Provisions
2-2-1: CREATION OF PLAN COMMISSION:
In order to achieve the purposes of this chapter, a plan commission consisting
of seven (7) qualified persons appointed in such manner and for such terms as
hereinafter prescribed in sections
2-2-2 and
2-2-3 of this chapter is hereby created under the authority of chapter 65,
article 11, division 12 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. All commission
members shall be residents of the village of Winfield, except that one member
may be a resident in unincorporated territory contained within the village's
comprehensive planning area. (Ord. 2014-01-02, 1-16-2014)
2-2-2: APPOINTMENT; MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION:
The president shall appoint seven (7) persons to serve on the plan commission
subject to confirmation by the corporate authorities. All members of the
commission shall serve as such without compensation. (Ord. 2009-05-12, 5-7-
2009)
2-2-3: TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES; REMOVALS:
One person shall be appointed chairman by the village president for a term of
one year. Thereafter, the chairman shall be elected at the annual meeting to be
held in the month of June. First appointments of the members shall be: two (2)
members for one year, two (2) members for two (2) years, and three (3) members
for three (3) years, and thereafter appointments shall be for three (3) years.
Members may be appointed for additional three (3) year terms. An appointment by
the president, subject to confirmation by the corporate authorities, to fill a
vacancy in an unexpired term shall be for the remainder of the term. Members
shall serve until their successors have been appointed. When a member of the
commission has been unable to or has failed to attend meetings for health,
business or other reasons during a consecutive period of four (4) months, such
absence shall be construed, after notice to the member, as resigning from the
commission, except where the president determines, after consultation with a
member of the commissioner's family, that attendance at meetings can and will
be resumed. A vacancy thus created shall be filled as in the case of other
vacancies. Any member of the commission may be removed from office in the
manner provided by law. (Ord. 2009-05-12, 5-7-2009)
2-2-4: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
The plan commission shall adopt such rules of procedure deemed necessary to
conduct meetings and public hearings and to carry out its duties, following
"Robert's Rules Of Order" in situations not covered by adopted rules. (Ord.
2009-05-12, 5-7-2009)
2-2-5: POWERS:
The plan commission shall have such powers as may be given to it by law, and
shall have, as is now provided by law, the following powers:
   A.   To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities a comprehensive
plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the village.
Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional
parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the official comprehensive plan,
or part thereof, of the village. This plan may include reasonable requirements
with reference to streets, alleys, public grounds and other improvements
hereinafter specified. The plan, as recommended by the plan commission, and as
thereafter adopted, may be made applicable, by the terms thereof, to land
situated within the corporate limits and contiguous territory not more than one
and one-half (1.5) miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any
municipality. Such plan may be implemented by ordinances:
      1.   Establishing reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for
resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in
respect to public improvements as herein defined;
      2.   Establishing reasonable requirements governing the location, width,
course and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public
service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks,
playgrounds, school grounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes,
stormwater drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage
collection and treatment; and
      3.   May designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the
recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation.
   B.   To recommend changes, from time to time, in the official comprehensive
plan.
   C.   To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities, from time to
time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the official
comprehensive plan.
   D.   To give aid to the municipal officials charged with the direction of
projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the
making of these projects and, generally, to promote the realization of the
official comprehensive plan.
   E.   To prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities schemes for
regulating or forbidding structures or activities which may hinder access to
solar energy necessary for the proper functioning of solar energy systems as
defined in section 1.2 of the comprehensive solar energy act of 1977, or to
recommend changes in such schemes.
   F.   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by this
section as may be conferred by the corporate authorities.
   G.   All testimony by witnesses at any hearing required by statute and
conducted by the plan commission shall be given under oath.
   H.   To provide advisory recommendations regarding Public Art Mural
Submissions.
   I.   For additional duties of the plan commission, see title 10, chapters 10
and 11 of this code.
(Ord. 2009-05-12, 5-7-2009; amd. Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-6: OFFICIAL COMPREHENSIVE PLAN:
   A.   Plan Adopted: The official comprehensive plan for the present and
future development and redevelopment of the village consists of two volumes
entitled
      1.   Winfield Comprehensive Plan, prepared by Teska Associates, and dated
May 1, 2014.
      2.   Town Center Vision 3.0 Report, prepared by Kon Savoy Consulting
Group and dated January 24, 2023 The official comprehensive plan, as previously
or hereafter amended by the village, shall be effective upon the expiration
often (10) days after the date of filing the plan or amendments thereto with
the recorder of deeds of DuPage County as provided by 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-12-7.
   B.   General Development Plan Report Adopted: The general development plan
report, part I, background studies for planning, and the general development
plan, as now adopted or hereafter amended, shall be and the same hereby are
adopted as part of the official comprehensive plan for the village as approved
and adopted by subsection A of this section.
(Ord. 97-4-21, 4-17-1997; amd. Ord. 2023-04-06, 4-6-2023)
2-2-7: PUBLIC ART MURAL PROGRAM:
2-2-7-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
   There is hereby created and established a Public Art Mural Program for the
Village.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-7-2: PURPOSE:
   The Public Art Mural Program is designed to enhance the character and
aesthetics of the community as well as embody walls with history, storytelling
and placemaking that will help distinguish the Village from other communities.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-7-3: DEFINITIONS:
PUBLIC ART MURAL: A large painting or other work of visual art applied directly
on the side exterior wall of a building visible from a public right-of-way or
other public area. A Public Art Mural shall not function as signage or
advertisement for an on-site or off-site business and shall not contain hidden
or overt text, logos, symbols, slogans or trademarks that convey commercial
content and/or advertise for products or services.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-7-4: PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION:
   The Plan and Zoning Commission shall manage and administer the Public Art
Mural Program on behalf of the Village. The Village Manager shall develop,
publish and, when necessary and prudent to the administration of the program,
may amend program guidelines consistent with this Subdivision to administer the
Public Art Mural Program on behalf of the Village and to guide participants on
the terms, conditions and requirements for participation in the program. The
Village Board of Trustees are authorized to issue resolutions approving Public
Art Murals as recommended by the Plan and Zoning Commission.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-7-5: ELIGIBILITY:
   To be eligible for the Public Art Mural Program, the subject property shall
be in the TC-Town Center, B-1 General Business, any commercial areas that are
part of a residential planned development (Prairie Trail Shopping Center,
Winfield Pointe) and any public park, with the appropriate Park District's
written permission.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-7-6: APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
A Public Art Mural application shall be submitted to the Village Manager's
office which includes the following documents:
   A.   A color rendering of the proposed mural, including dimensions and a
site rendering of the proposed wall or fa9ade upon which the mural would be
installed or affixed.
   B.   An aerial map providing the location where the proposed mural would be
installed and photographs of the site location and its immediate surroundings.
   C.   A narrative that includes a written description of the proposed mural,
the project timeline, budget and funding sources.
   D.   Resume or biography for each artist involved in the design of the mural
that includes a list of examples of their previous mural projects work and the
location of each project.
   E.   A maintenance plan that includes the proposed timeline or lifespan of
the mural, information on wall preparation, proposed materials, installation
process, information on the intended protective coating to be used and a
statement attesting that the coating will be applied in order to preserve the
integrity of the building, structure and mural.
   F.   The applicant shall provide a Maintenance and Removal of Mural
Agreement, executed by the artist and property owner, which shall contain a
waiver of the Visual Artists' Rights Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 106, 106A and 113, as
amended, executed by the artist.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-7-7: STANDARDS FOR APPROVAL:
A Public Art Mural application shall be reviewed according to the following
standards:
   A.   The Public Art Mural content shall meet the Code definition and be
focused on presenting history, storytelling or placemaking content.
   B.   The Public Art Mural content should inspire, educate or advocate for at
least one aspect of the community vibrancy, diversity, traditions or family-
friendly character of Winfield.
   C.   The applicant demonstrates that the intended materials will be
effective for long-term durability and exposure to the elements, and that the
Public Art Mural will be sealed with anti-graffiti and UV resistant coating by
the artist upon completion of the mural.
   D.   The applicant shall provide a schedule for maintenance which the
property owner has agreed to follow for a five (5)-year term following
completion of mural installation.
   E.   The Public Art Mural will not create a danger for motorists or
pedestrians, nor will it limit the use or enjoyment of an adjacent property or
a property with a clear line of sight to the mural.
   F.   The surface on which the Public Art Mural is to be applied does have
appropriate structural integrity to support the chosen application method.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
2-2-7-8: INSTALLATION PROVISIONS:
A Public Art Mural shall be installed in compliance with the following
provisions:
   A.   Public Art Murals shall be permitted uses in the TC-Town Center, B-
1 General Business zoning districts, any commercial areas that are part of a
residential planned development (Prairie Trail Shopping Center, Winfield
Pointe), and any public park, with the appropriate Park District's written
permission.
   B.   Public Art Murals are limited to one (1) wall per building and one (1)
per zoning lot.
   C.   Public Art Murals are limited to secondary facades, not primary street
frontages.
   D.   Public Art Murals shall not interrupt major architectural features such
as doors and windows.
   E.   A Public Art Mural may not extend more than six inches (6") from the
plane of the wall it is placed upon.
   F.   Public Art Murals shall be applied with materials manufactured with the
expectation of long-term durability and exposure to the elements.
   G.   Public Art Murals shall be sealed with anti-graffiti and UV resistant
coating by the artist upon completion of the mural.
   H.   Public Art Murals shall not be illuminated by artificial lighting.
   I.   Property owners on both sides of the same block where an approved
Public Art Mural will be installed shall be notified in writing of the
installation.
(Ord. 2025-05-09, 5-15-2025)
CHAPTER 3
ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS 1
SECTION:
2-3-1: Board Continued; Composition And Terms
2-3-2: Appointments; Vacancies; Removals
2-3-3: Organization
2-3-4: Compensation
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-11-1-2 of this code.
2-3-1: BOARD CONTINUED; COMPOSITION AND TERMS:
There is hereby continued as previously established a zoning board of appeals
for the village. Said board shall consist of seven (7) members to serve
respectively for terms of five (5) years. All board members shall be residents
of the village of Winfield, except that one member may be a resident in
unincorporated territory contained within the village's comprehensive planning
area. (Ord. 2014-01-02, 1-16-2014)
2-3-2: APPOINTMENTS; VACANCIES; REMOVALS:
All appointments to the zoning board of appeals shall be made by the village
president subject to approval of the board of trustees. The board shall elect
from its membership a chairperson. Said chairperson and members of the board
shall serve until the expiration of their current terms or until their
respective successors have been duly appointed and qualified. Vacancies shall
be filled for the unexpired terms of the members whose places have become
vacant in the manner herein provided for the appointment of such members. The
president, subject to the approval of the board of trustees, shall have the
power to remove any member of the zoning board of appeals. (Ord. 687, 3-28-
1985)
2-3-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Meetings: All meetings of the zoning board of appeals shall be held at
the call of the chairman, and at such other times as the zoning board of
appeals may determine. All testimony by witnesses at any hearing provided for
in the zoning ordinance 1  shall be given under oath. The chairperson, or in
his absence the acting chairperson, may administer oaths and compel attendance
of witnesses. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. The board
shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon
every question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating that fact, and
shall also keep records of its examinations and other official actions.
   B.   Rules Of Procedure: The zoning board of appeals shall adopt its own
rules of procedure not in conflict with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-13-
3 and the zoning ordinance.
   C.   Voting: The concurring vote of four (4) members of the zoning board of
appeals shall be necessary on any matter upon which it is authorized to make a
recommendation. A member who did not attend the public hearing can vote if he
reviews the transcript of the hearing and complies with 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-13-3. (Ord. 687, 3-28-1985)
 
Notes
1 2. See title 10 of this code.
2-3-4: COMPENSATION:
Members of the zoning board of appeals shall serve without compensation. (Ord.
687, 3-28-1985)

CHAPTER 8
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND COMMUNICATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-8-1: Commission Created
2-8-2: Appointment, Term And Removal Of Members
2-8-3: Officers; Bylaws; Meetings
2-8-4: Purpose, Powers And Duties
2-8-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created an economic development and communication commission of
the village which is now renamed to the marketing and communications
commission. (Ord. 2016-05-11, 5-5-2016; amd. Ord. 2019-08-19, 8-15-2019)
2-8-2: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
The marketing and communications commission shall consist of eleven (11)
members:
   A.   Up to two (2) members may be non-residents falling into either or both
of the following categories: one (1) non-resident living in unincorporated
property located within the boundaries of Winfield's comprehensive planning
area and/or one (1) resident or non-resident who is an owner or representative
of a business or non-profit entity located within the village's boundaries.
   B.   Up to two (2) village trustees.
   C.   The remaining members shall be residents of Winfield. They shall be
appointed to overlapping terms by the village president with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees.
The initial appointed term of each member at the formation of the commission
shall be three (3) years, two (2) years, or one (1) year, provided, however,
each commissioner shall serve until a successor is duly appointed and
qualified. The terms of such commission members shall be staggered so that not
more than four (4) terms shall expire in any one (1) year. Subsequent terms for
renewal or replacement for all members will be for a three (3) year term. Any
member of the commission may be removed by the village president with the
advice and consent of the board of trustees. (Ord. 2016-05-11, 5-5-2016; amd.
Ord. 2019-08-19, 8-15-2019)
2-8-3: OFFICERS; BYLAWS; MEETINGS:
   A.   Chairman Of The Commission: The commission shall elect its own
chairperson from amongst its members and the chairman’s tenure should coincide
with the term the person has on the commission. The commission may determine
such other offices and elect such other officers as may be necessary to fulfill
its duties and responsibilities.
   B.   Bylaws: The commission shall adopt such rules governing its procedures
and regulating its business as it shall from time to time deem appropriate.
   C.   Meetings: The commission shall meet from time to time on the call of
the chairman, provided, however, that the commission shall meet at least ten
(10) meetings per annum. (Ord. 2016-05-11, 5-5-2016; amd. Ord. 2019-08-19, 8-
15-2019)
2-8-4: PURPOSE, POWERS AND DUTIES:
The purpose of the commission is to:
   A.   Make recommendations to the village president, board of trustees, and
village staff that would facilitate and improve communication between the
village and the residents of the community and local businesses.
   B.   Work with, advise and assist the village president, board of trustees
and village staff on communications media, including, but not limited to, the
village newsletter, village website, social media, guidelines for emergency
communications, cable public access channel, public relations, and other
marketing or media used to promote the village and inform the residents.
   C.   Propose, work with, and advise the village president and the board of
trustees on technology improvements including, but not limited to,
communication technologies.
   D.   Work with and advise the village president, board of trustees and
village staff on proposals and contracts incidental to the purpose of the
commission.
   E.   Propose, develop, coordinate and advise the village president, board of
trustees and village staff on initiatives related to the branding, marketing,
and promotion of the village.
   F.   Propose initiatives and advise the village president, board of trustees
and village staff on issues related to new    ordinances, and changes to
existing ordinances, that would improve communications, technology.
   G.   Perform such duties as assigned to it from time to time by the village
president and board of trustees.
   H.   Serve as the lead commission or as a participating commission on
specific assignments given by the village board incidental to the purpose of
the commission.
   I.   Work or propose marketing actions to attract development to all areas
of the village.
   J.   With approval of the village board, coordinate marketing and
promotional economic activities that benefit village business and residents.
(Ord. 2016-05-11, 5-5-2016; amd. Ord. 2019-08-19, 8-15-2019)

CHAPTER 11
ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCE COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-11-1: Created
2-11-2: Appointment, Term And Removal Of Members
2-11-3: Officers; Bylaws; Meetings
2-11-4: Purpose, Powers And Duties
2-11-1: CREATED:
There is hereby created an administration and finance committee of the village
of Winfield. (Ord. 2006-11-53, 11-20-2006)
2-11-2: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
The administration and finance committee shall consist of the village
treasurer, three (3) village board members and a village resident who shall be
appointed by the village president. The village manager and finance director
shall staff the committee and have nonvoting status. Any member of the
committee may be removed by the village president for any reason. (Ord. 2006-
11-53, 11-20-2006)
2-11-3: OFFICERS; BYLAWS; MEETINGS:
   A.   Leadership Of The Committee: The chairman and vice chairman of the
committee shall be appointed by the village president and shall serve for a two
(2) year term or until a successor is duly appointed and qualified.
   B.   Bylaws: The committee shall operate under the following set of bylaws:
      1.   Notices of meetings shall be posted and distributed to the members
of the media in accordance with state statutes.
      2.   Agendas and materials for meetings shall be distributed to members
not less than three (3) calendar days prior to the scheduled meeting.
      3.   Minutes of the committee meetings shall be kept in accordance with
state statutes.
      4.   The outline of the meeting order shall be as follows:
         a.   Call to order; roll call.
         b.   Approval of minutes.
         c.   Review of investments.
         d.   Old business.
         e.   New business.
         f.   Executive session (if required).
      5.   Advisory matters to be presented to the village board of final
resolution shall be accompanied by a voted upon motion of the committee.
   C.   Meetings: The committee shall meet from time to time on the call of the
chairman, provided, however, that the committee shall maintain at least one
meeting date per quarter. No meeting will be called unless proper notification
has been made in accordance with state statute. (Ord. 2006-11-53, 11-20-2006)
2-11-4: PURPOSE, POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The purpose of the committee is to facilitate recommendations to the
village president and board of trustees with regard to financial and
administration matters, and provide guidance on the village's investment
activities, pursuant to the village's investment policy. The areas of
responsibility shall include providing direction to the finance director and
treasurer on the investment of idle village funds, and reviewing and
recommending to the village board on:
      1.   The annual operating and capital improvement budgets of the village;
      2.   The selection of the auditing firm;
      3.   Results of the annual audit and acceptance of the same;
      4.   The long range financial plan;
      5.   The long range capital improvement plan;
      6.   Amendments to the annual budget appropriation; fees, charges and
taxes;
      7.   Personnel rules and regulations;
      8.   Matters of intergovernmental relations; and
      9.   The annual pay and benefit plan.
   B.   The committee shall also perform such duties as assigned to it from
time to time by the village president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2006-11-53,
11-20-2006)

PUBLIC WORKS COMMITTEE
SECTION:
2-13-1: Committee Created
2-13-2: Appointment, Term And Removal Of Members

2-13-4: Purpose, Powers And Duties
2-13-1: COMMITTEE CREATED:
There is hereby created a public works committee of the village of Winfield.
(Ord. 2007-6-35, 6-21-2007)
2-13-2: APPOINTMENT, TERM AND REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
   A.   Official Members: The public works committee shall consist of two (2)
village board members and five (5) citizens at large, all subject to
appointment by the village president and confirmation by a vote of the village
trustees. The village manager, village engineer, and public works
superintendent or their designees shall staff the committee and have nonvoting
status. Members at large shall serve for two (2) year terms and may serve
consecutive terms. Any member of the committee may be removed by the village
president for any reason. All citizen at large committee members shall be
residents of the village, except that one member may be a resident in
unincorporated territory contained within the village's comprehensive planning
area. (Ord. 2014-01-02, 1-16-2014)
2-13-3: OFFICERS; BYLAWS; MEETINGS:
   A.   Leadership Of The Committee: The chairman and vice chairman of the
committee shall be appointed by the village president and shall serve for a two
(2) year term or until a successor is duly appointed and qualified. The
chairman and vice chairman may serve consecutive terms.
   B.   Bylaws: The committee shall operate under the following set of bylaws:
      1.   Notices of meetings shall be posted and distributed to the members
of the media in accordance with state statutes.
      2.   Agendas and materials for meetings shall be distributed to members
not less than three (3) calendar days prior to the scheduled meeting.
      3.   Minutes of the committee meetings shall be kept in accordance with
state statutes.
      4.   The outline of the meeting order shall be as follows:
         a.   Call to order; roll call
         b.   Approval of minutes
         c.   Public input
         d.   Old business
         e.   New business
         f.   Executive session (if required).
      5.   Advisory matters to be presented to the village board of final
resolution shall be accompanied by a voted upon motion of the committee.
   C.   Meetings: The committee shall meet from time to time on the call of the
chairman; provided, however, that the committee shall maintain at least one
meeting date per quarter. No meeting will be called unless proper notification
has been made in accordance with state statute. (Ord. 2007-6-35, 6-21-2007)
2-13-4: PURPOSE, POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The purpose of the committee is to facilitate recommendations to the
village president and board of trustees with regard to public works matters.
The areas of responsibility shall include research, review and making
recommendations to the village board on:
      1.   Capital improvement plans and actual projects;
      2.   Utility rate studies in concert with the administration finance
committee;
      3.   Public works related studies;
      4.   Public works related grants;
      5.   Stormwater and flooding issues;
      6.   Environmental and community health issues;
      7.   Traffic and transportation;
      8.   Monthly statistical report of the public works department; and
      9.   Bids for the purchase of public works equipment. (Ord. 2013-02-08,
2-21-2013)
   B.   The committee shall also perform such duties as assigned to it from
time to time by the village president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2007-6-35,
6-21-2007)
CHAPTER 14

SECTION:

2-14-2: Setting Time And Place For Public Hearing
