   Notes:
       1.    In order to prevent damage to village streets or disruption of
traffic, the village may require a special permit before authorizing the
applicant to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or
weight specified or otherwise not in conformity with the provisions of this
section upon any roads under the jurisdiction of the village if such load is
composed of a single object that cannot reasonably be dismantled or
disassembled. These special permits may require additional administrative,
engineering, and road damage fees.
       2.    Vehicles shall require a police escort. The number of police
escorts shall be determined by the village based on the density of the area and
other safety concerns at the sole discretion of the village. The fees for each
escort shall be $40.00 per officer per hour and a minimum of 2 hours' payment
is required.
If a vehicle requires a permit due to multiple weight and/or dimensions issues,
the total fee shall be based on the largest individual weight or dimension
factor only.
   J.   Drawn Accounts: A drawn down account, or escrow account, can be
established by the permit applicant for the purposes of depositing money for
use, as needed, to be automatically withdrawn upon request of the applicant for
payment of permit fees. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to
maintain a current balance in their draw down account to cover any and all fees
for permit requests.
   K.   Temporary Load Limits: In order to prevent potential damage to village
streets and bridges, the village manager shall have the power to impose
temporary vehicle load limits on streets or portions thereof, in order to allow
the village engineer time to investigate the situation. Any such temporary
limitation shall be reviewed as soon as possible by the village board of
trustees at their next regular meeting.
The village manager shall have the power to limit temporarily the use of
streets or portions thereof to certain types of vehicles and shall post or have
posted in conspicuous places signs showing the limitations thus imposed.
   L.   Penalty: In addition to other village remedies set forth herein, any
person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to a fine of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and each day that the violation occurs or
continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 2002-9-39, 9-5-2002)
6-1-5: BLOCK PARTIES; STREET CLOSURES:
Upon receipt of an application for a block party or similar event, not less
than thirty (30) days before the proposed event, the village manager, after
consultation with the chief of police, may authorize a permit to allow the
temporary closure of specific streets to general traffic for the event. The
permit shall be valid only for a specific period of time, which shall be set
forth in the permit. The applicant shall be responsible for the payment of any
costs incurred by the village in providing equipment or services for the event,
and said payment shall be made prior to the issuance of the permit. The permit
application shall be denied if, in the reasonable discretion and determination
of the village manager or the chief of police, the proposed closure of the
specific streets would have a materially adverse effect on the free flow of
traffic in the area adjacent to the event or would otherwise jeopardize the
health, safety or welfare of the village or its residents. (Ord. 2005-02-01, 2-
3-2005)
6-1-6: CORNER SETBACK AREAS; RIGHT OF WAY OBSTRUCTIONS:
6-1-6-1: CORNER SETBACK AREA DEFINED:
   A.   At the intersection of any village street improved for public traffic,
there shall be a corner setback area. The corner setback area shall be
established using the measurements found in figure 1 of this section. The
village's setback areas reflect the different classifications of streets in the
community, and the concomitant maximum speeds of traffic that may be found on
the particular street.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/e69e56974fd8eb3967f8b4473ce72c7a644bafb1/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2150.gif]
   B.   The village manager shall designate each street within the corporate
limits of the village as a local, collector or arterial street for the purpose
of this code, which shall be on file in the office of the village clerk. The
following definitions shall apply to said designations:
ARTERIAL STREETS: Designated state of Illinois or DuPage County routes or major
village streets that allow traffic movement between area service highways and
state routes, and roads of lesser importance. They serve as principal routes
between retail, commercial, and industrial sites. The typical width of arterial
streets is in excess of fifty feet (50').
COLLECTOR STREETS: Connect residential subdivisions and gather traffic from
local streets and channel it onto the arterial road network. The typical
pavement width of a collector street is between thirty six (36) to forty eight
feet (48').
LOCAL STREETS: Provide direct access to adjacent properties and are most
commonly found within residential subdivisions. The typical width of a local
street is less than thirty six feet (36'). (Ord. 2007-8-43, 8-16-2007)
6-1-6-2: PROHIBITION OF OBSTRUCTIONS IN CORNER SETBACK AREA:
The corner setback area shall be maintained free of sight distance obstructions
to promote safe movement of vehicle, bicycle and pedestrian traffic through the
intersection. It shall be a violation of this Code for any property owner or
other responsible party to maintain trees, shrubs or other landscaping elements
or to erect, or cause to be erected, any obstruction such as a fence, awning,
sign, or other structure that is at a height greater than thirty inches (30")
above the top of the adjacent curb grade, or at a height greater than thirty
six inches (36") above the nearest pavement surface where there are no curbs.
(Ord. 2007-8-43, 8-16-2007)
6-1-6-3: PROHIBITION OF OBSTRUCTIONS IN PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY TRAFFIC AREAS:
The public right-of-way traffic area shall be maintained free of sight and
mobility obstructions to promote safe movement of vehicle, bicycle and
pedestrian traffic. The public right-of- way traffic area shall also be
maintained free of obstructions which adversely affect improvements installed
to facilitate the movement of vehicles, bicycles and pedestrians or adversely
affect public utility mains, service laterals and other appurtenances. (Ord.
2007-8-43, 8-16-2007)
6-1-6-4: ENFORCEMENT:
When any prohibited obstruction as defined in this Code exists, a notice shall
be sent by the Police Chief or his/her designated representative, by first
class United States mail to the owner or responsible party. Such notice shall
describe the condition, state the work necessary to remedy the condition, and
specify the time within which the necessary work must be performed. Failure of
the property owner or responsible party to correct such condition within the
specified time shall be deemed a violation of this Code. (Ord. 2007-8-43, 8-16-
2007)
6-1-6-5: NUISANCE ABATEMENT; PROHIBITED OBSTRUCTIONS:
   A.   Any manmade or geologic features that pose obstructions as defined in
this Code are hereby grandfathered.
   B.   Notwithstanding the above provisions, if the owner or responsible party
fails to abate any of the obstructions described in this Code in a timely
manner or the condition is a recurring one requiring undue Village personnel
time to monitor and correct, the Police Chief or designee may invoke the
procedures to abate a nuisance pursuant to this Code, including summary
abatement of a condition that causes or constitutes an imminent or immediate
danger to the health, welfare or safety of the public or interferes with or
jeopardizes the public's use of any street, sidewalk, path or right-of-way
through the use of Village or contractual forces. (Ord. 2007-8-43, 8-16-2007)
6-1-6-6: PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section
6-1-6, shall be punished by a fine as provided in section
13-1-4 of this Code for any offense. (Ord. 2019-02-01, 2-7-2019)
CHAPTER 2
STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING
SECTION:
6-2-1: No Parking Places
6-2-2: General Parking Restrictions
6-2-3: Parking Restrictions Or Prohibitions On Certain Streets
6-2-4: Method Of Parking
6-2-5: Passenger And Freight Loading Zones
6-2-6: Municipal Parking
6-2-1: NO PARKING PLACES:
   A.   Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in
compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic
control device, no person shall:
      1.   Stop, stand or park a vehicle:
         a.   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge
or curb of a street.
         b.   On a sidewalk.
         c.   Within an intersection.
         d.   On a crosswalk.
         e.   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet
(30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone,
unless the traffic authority indicates a different length by signs or markings.
         f.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic.
         g.   Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or
within a highway tunnel.
         h.   On any railroad tracks.
         i.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping.
         j.   On the left side of a two-way street.
         k.   In any parking space, including private or public off street
parking facility, specifically reserved by the posting of an official sign for
motor vehicles bearing registration plates or decals issued to a handicapped
person or to a disabled veteran unless the motor vehicle bears registration
plates or decals issued to a handicapped person or to a disabled veteran. (Ord.
689, 4-25-1985)
         l.   On a front, side or back yard area, unless parked on an improved
surface, as defined in subsection 10-9-4H8c(1)(D) of this code. (Ord. 2014-12-
41, 12-18-2014)
      2.   Stand or park a vehicle, if unoccupied:
         a.   In front of a public or private driveway.
         b.   Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant.
         c.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection.
         d.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing
signal, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway.
         e.   Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire
station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station
within seventy five feet (75') of said entrance (when properly signposted).
         f.   At any place where official signs or yellow painted curbs
prohibit standing.
      3.   Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the
purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or
passengers:
         a.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad
crossing.
         b.   At any place where official signs or yellow painted curbs
prohibit parking.
   B.   No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any
such prohibited area or away from a curb such a distance as is unlawful. (Ord.
507, 2-9-1978)
6-2-2: GENERAL PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Parking Not To Obstruct Traffic: No person shall park any vehicle upon
a street, other than an alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to
leave available less than ten feet (10') of the width of the roadway for free
movement of vehicular traffic.
   B.   Alleys: No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner
or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet (10') of the
width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person
shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to
block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. (Ord. 507, 2-9-1978)
   C.   All Night Parking 1 : No person shall park a vehicle on any street or
along or upon any right of way of any public street for a period of time longer
than thirty (30) minutes between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six
o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any day; except, that division I vehicles may park on
streets twenty four feet (24') or more in width during those hours but only on
the side of the street posted to allow such parking.
      1.   Exemptions: Any resident who may require permission to leave a
vehicle on a village roadway during the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and
six o'clock (6:00) A.M. must:
         a.   Contact the village of Winfield police department at 630-933-7160
or submit the request using the village online form prior to two o'clock (2:00)
A.M. of the day requested. Permission will be granted unless the vehicle will
cause a hazardous road condition, interfere with village operations or exceed
the allowable number of requests.
         b.   Requests receiving permission are limited to three (3) requests
within a thirty (30) day period.
         c.   No overnight parking permission will be granted when there are
two (2) or more inches of snowfall. (Ord. 2014-08-29, 8-21-2014)
   D.   Narrow Streets: No person shall park upon any street when the width of
the roadway does not exceed twenty feet (20'). (Ord. 625, 8-26-1982)
   E.   Parking For Certain Purposes Prohibited:
      1.   Washing Or Repair: No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway
or along or upon any right of way of any public street for the principal
purpose of washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs
necessitated by an emergency.
      2.   Vehicles For Sale; Selling Merchandise: No person shall park or
permit the parking of any automobile, truck, trailer, tractor or any similar
vehicle along or upon any roadway or street or along or upon any right of way
of any public street for the purpose of displaying such vehicle for sale, or to
park any vehicle from which merchandise is being sold. Such vehicles may only
be placed for display on the driveway of private property. (Ord. 2003-11-56,
11-6-2003)
   F.   Adjacent To Schools: The village president and board of trustees are
hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon either or both
sides of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in
his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation.
When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either side of a
street adjacent to any school property as authorized herein, no person shall
park a vehicle in any such designated place.
   G.   One-Way Streets And Roadways:
      1.   One-Way Streets: The village president and board of trustees are
authorized to erect signs upon the left hand side of any one-way street to
prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles, and when such signs are in place,
no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such left hand side in violation
of any such sign.
      2.   One-Way Roadways: In the event a highway includes two (2) or more
separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such
roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left hand side of
such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or
parking. The president and board of trustees are authorized to determine when
standing or parking may be permitted upon the left hand side of any such one-
way roadway and to erect signs giving notice thereof.
   H.   Hazardous Or Congested Places: The president and board of trustees are
hereby authorized to determine and designate by proper signs, places not
exceeding one hundred feet (100') in length in which the stopping, standing or
parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would
cause unusual delay to traffic.
When official signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized
herein, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated
place.
   I.   Bus And Taxicab Stands: The president and board of trustees are hereby
authorized to determine and designate by proper signs taxicab stands, and no
person other than a taxicab operator shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other
than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been
officially designated and appropriately signed; except, that the driver of a
passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while
actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not
interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone.
   J.   After Snowfall: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on the right
of way of any public street in the village at any time within twelve (12) hours
after a snowfall of two inches (2") or more has occurred, unless the snow has
been plowed off or otherwise removed from such right of way. (Ord. 507, 2-9-
1978)
   K.   Village Employees; Village Business: When a sign is erected limiting
parking except for village employees or for the transaction of business in the
village hall, no person shall park a vehicle in the area so signed except a
village employee or for the purpose described. (Ord. 681, 12-27-1984)
   L.   Public Parking Lot Permits: When signs have been erected upon any
public parking lot indicating that parking is prohibited except by permit only,
no person shall park any vehicle in or upon said lot without displaying from
the bracket supporting the inside rearview mirror at the inside center of the
windshield in a manner visible from the outside of said vehicle, a valid
parking permit issued by the village. The fee, effective with the July-
September 2010 quarter, for such parking permit shall be one hundred twenty
dollars ($120.00) per quarter. No person shall park such vehicle in any space
other than the space for which a permit has been issued and in any other
position than a head in position, so that the rear of the vehicle is closer to
the parking aisle than is the front of the vehicle. (Ord. 2010-04-11, 4-15-
2010)
   M.   Parking Commercial Vehicles In Residential Neighborhoods:
      1.   General Prohibition: Except as specifically permitted in section
6-2-5 of this chapter, no commercial vehicle as defined herein may be parked or
stored in a residential neighborhood other than in a completely enclosed garage
except for loading or unloading of household belongings between six o'clock (6:
00) A.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight for the purpose of moving a
personal residence or for deliveries, repairs, construction, maintenance, or
service calls.
      2.   Specifically Permitted Regardless Of Presence Of Commercial
Lettering Or Logos:
         a.   Pickup trucks, cargo vans, sprinter vans with a state vehicle
license of class D or less and enclosed trailers may be parked anywhere on a
private residential driveway provided the height of the vehicle/trailer,
including any attached accessories, does not exceed nine feet (9') in height.
         b.   Pickup trucks, cargo vans, sprinter vans and enclosed trailers
over nine feet (9') in height, step vans, panel vans, box trucks and extended
wheel base limousines, may be parked on private residential driveways provided:
1) any such vehicle/trailer is parked outside actual front, actual corner side,
and required interior side yard and at least ten feet (10') from the rear
property lines and 2) any such motorized vehicle either has a valid state
license of class D or less or a livery license plate.
      3.   Special Use Commercial Vehicles: The outdoor parking of a single
commercial vehicle not specifically allowed herein may be approved as a special
use under provisions for special uses in section
1-7-5 of this code. (Ord. 2016-12-28, 12-1-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  6-3-7 of this title.
6-2-3: PARKING RESTRICTIONS OR PROHIBITIONS ON CERTAIN STREETS:
   A.   Application Of Provisions: The provisions of this section prohibiting
the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or as
indicated on official signs except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to
avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a
police officer or official traffic control device.
   B.   Parking Prohibited At All Times 1 : When signs are erected giving
notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the
streets so marked.
   C.   Parking Prohibited During Certain Hours 2 : The village president and
board of trustees may erect traffic signs prohibiting parking on any streets or
locations within the municipality during certain hours. When such signs are
erected giving notice of the prohibition against parking, no person shall stop,
stand or park a vehicle within the area or place during the hours specified by
such signs.
   D.   Time Limit Parking: The president and board of trustees may erect
traffic signs limiting the time for parking vehicles on certain streets or
locations within the municipality. When such signs are erected giving notice of
the limitation of time for parking, no person shall stop, stand or park a
vehicle for longer than the time specified by such signs. (Ord. 507, 2-9-1978)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  6-3-5 of this title.
2 2. See also section
  6-3-7 of this title.
6-2-4: METHOD OF PARKING:
   A.   Standing Or Parking Close To And Parallel To Curb: Except as otherwise
provided in this section, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway where
there are adjacent curbs shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand
wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within twelve inches (12") of the right
hand curb.
   B.   Angle Parking:
      1.   Determination Of Angle Parking; Signs Posted: The president and
board of trustees shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be
permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not
be indicated upon any federal aid or state highway within this village unless
the state has determined by resolution or order entered in its minutes that the
roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with
the free movement of traffic.
Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing
traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the
street.
      2.   Obedience To Angle Parking Signs Or Markings: On those streets which
have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a
vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by
such signs or markings.
      3.   Permits For Loading Or Unloading At An Angle To The Curb: The
president and board of trustees are authorized to issue special permits to
permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or
unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such
permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real
property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the
privilege as therein stated and authorized herein.
It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the
special terms or conditions of any such permit. (Ord. 507, 2-9-1978)
6-2-5: PASSENGER AND FREIGHT LOADING ZONES:
   A.   Authority To Designate Loading Zones: The village president and board
of trustees are hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and
freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs
indicating the same and stating the hours during which the provisions of this
section are applicable.
   B.   Permits For Curb Loading Zones: The president and board of trustees
shall not hereafter designate or sign any curb loading zone upon special
request of any person unless such person makes application for a permit for
such zone and for two (2) signs to indicate the ends of each such zone. The
village board, upon granting a permit at no charge and issuing such signs, may,
by general regulations, impose conditions upon the use of such signs and for
reimbursement of the village for the value thereof in the event of their loss
or damage and their return in the event of misuse or upon expiration of permit.
Every such permit shall expire at the end of one year.
   C.   Standing In Curb Loading Zones:
      1.   Passenger Loading Zones: No person shall stop, stand or park a
vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious
loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb
loading zone during the hours when the regulations applicable to such curb
loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three (3)
minutes.
      2.   Freight Loading Zones: No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle
for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and
delivery or pick up and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight
curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are
in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials
exceed thirty (30) minutes.
   D.   Public Carrier Stops And Stands:
      1.   Authority To Designate: The president and board of trustees are
hereby authorized and required to establish bus stops, bus stands, taxicab
stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such
public streets in such places and in such number as they shall determine to be
of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop,
bus stand, taxicab stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate
signs.
      2.   Use Of Bus And Taxicab Stands:
         a.   The operator of a bus shall:
            (1)   Not stand or park such vehicle upon any street at any place
other than a bus stand so designated as provided herein.
            (2)   Not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the
purpose of loading or unloading passengers or their baggage other than at a bus
stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone so designated as provided herein,
except in case of an emergency. (Ord. 507, 2-9-1978)
            (3)   Enter a bus stop, bus stand or passenger loading zone on a
public street in such a manner that the bus, when stopped to load or unload
passengers or baggage, shall be in a position with the right front wheel of
such vehicle not farther than twelve inches (12") from the curb and the bus
approximately parallel to the curb so as not to unduly impede the movement of
other vehicular traffic. (Ord. 507, 2-9-1978; amd. 1989 Code)
         b.   The operator of a taxicab shall not stand or park such vehicle
upon any street at any place other than in a taxicab stand so designated as
provided herein. This provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab
from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking
regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the
expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. (Ord. 507, 2-9-1978)
6-2-6: MUNICIPAL PARKING:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and
phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
   COLLECTION/FEE BOX: A slotted box or other receptacle into which a parking
fee is deposited thereby granting a vehicle authority to park in a designated
or numbered parking space.
   MOBILE PHONE APP: A computer program designed to run on smartphones, tablet
computers and other mobile devices.
   MUNICIPAL PARKING LOT: Any off street area designated for metered, reserved,
permitted or time limit parking.
   RESTRICTED OR TIME LIMIT PARKING ZONE: A certain designated section of a
public street or Municipal parking lot in which parking is permitted for
designated periods and for which signs are posted giving notice of such
periods.
   USER FEES: A sum of money paid by the individual who chooses to access a
service or facility. Examples of user fees include parking charges the
individual directly pays for accessing and using a service which is provided.
   VEHICLE: Any device by which any person or property may be transported upon
a public highway, except those operated upon rails and permanent tracks.
   B.   Fee Or Daily Parking Lots: Fee or daily parking lots shall apply to all
public parking lots owned, leased or controlled by the Village in which charges
for parking are imposed and collected by means of the user depositing a fee as
hereinafter set forth, in United States currency or an acceptable form of
payment, in receptacles known as fee collection boxes located in respective
parking lots. Fees deposited must be appropriated to the proper numbered space
for the location which the vehicle is parked. All definitions set forth in
subsection A of this section shall also apply to the terms used in this
section.
      1.   The following lots are hereby designated as daily fee parking lots
and are authorized only for the parking of vehicles for which the proper fee
has been prepaid on a monthly basis, has been paid on a daily basis, by
depositing the proper fee in the appropriate slot of a collection box in the
form of United States currency or credit or the proper fee has been paid by
utilizing the Village approved mobile phone app, except those spaces otherwise
designated by the posting of signs:
         a.   Metra lot, situated on Jewell Road, just north of Winfield Metra
Station.
         b.   Highlake Road lot, situated along Highlake Road, just west of the
U.S. Post Office.
         c.   Church Street, situated along Church Street, between Chicago
Avenue and Liberty Street.
         d.   St. John the Baptist parking lot, situated at the corner of
Church Street and Liberty Street.
         e.   Jewell Road lot, situated on Jewell Road, just east of Church
Street.
         f.   Church Street lot, situated at the intersection of Church Street
and Chicago Avenue.
         g.   Chicago Avenue lot, situated along Chicago Avenue, north and
south sides of the one-way roadway.
   C.   Employee Parking Permits:
      1.   The Village of Winfield shall designate permanent and temporary
parking areas for employees only. The designated parking lots shall be properly
signed and all authorized users of these designated parking spaces shall
display a Village issued employee E numbered parking permit. Effective July 1,
2015, all persons eligible for an employee permit and/or persons needing a
replacement permit shall remit the fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each
employee parking placard.
         a.   The employee permits shall only be valid during the times in
which the employee is actively engaged in their course of employment and shall
not be valid for any other purposes such as commuting on the train.
         b.   The employee permits shall only be valid to the employee to which
it was issued.
            (1)   Any person convicted of violating the terms of subsection D1a
of this section or this subsection D1b shall be fined according to the Village
schedule of fines and have their employee parking privileges revoked.
   D.   Issuance And Sale Of Parking Permits:
      1.   The Village shall cause suitable reserved parking permits to be
prepared and made available for issuance and sale. Such permits shall designate
the permit parking lot for which they are issued. Permits for different time
periods, if any, or for different lots, shall be designated by different colors
or in some other manner approved by the Village Manager.
      2.   Permits shall be offered for sale by the Finance Department during
regular business hours at the Village office in advance of the commencement of
each calendar quarter, subject to the following:
         a.   Permit purchases and renewals are issued and sold by the Finance
Department when such permits are made available for sale at the Village
offices.
         b.   Permits are sold quarterly and must be purchased by the deadline
set forth in and are subject to the regulations and policies set forth by the
Village of Winfield.
         c.   Quarterly permits must be renewed at least seven (7) days prior
to the beginning of the new quarter (quarters begin on January 1, April 1, July
1 and October 1 of each year).
         d.   Late fees for quarterly permits are as follows:
            (1)   A ten percent (10%) late fee will be charged to permits
purchased after the seventh day prior to the beginning of the new quarter, but
prior to the first day of the new quarter.
            (2)   A twenty percent (20%) late fee will be charged to permits
purchased after the first day of the new quarter has begun, but prior to the
fifth day after the new quarter has begun.
            (3)   If the appropriate payment is not received on or before the
fifth calendar day of the new quarter, the permit holder forfeits the permit. A
permit holder may not utilize the permit parking lot without a valid permit
displayed.
         e.   In the event that a current permit holder fails to renew their
permit in the time outlined above, they can appeal their case for
reconsideration to the Administrative and Finance Committee, by filing their
request in writing, to the attention of the Village Finance Director.
      The following reasons for possible consideration for failure to renew
their permit in the time outlined in subsections E2c and E2d of this section,
will be either a death in the immediate family of the permit holder or illness
of the permit holder or family member of the permit holder for which the permit
holder provided necessary care before the renewal deadline. In both cases, the
permit holder will be required to provide written documentation or evidence
supporting the above considerations.
         f.   The Village will also maintain a permit parking waiting list. The
process of the waiting list is subject to the permit parking regulations and
policies set forth by the Village of Winfield. Any person on the waiting list
who violates subsection E4, E5 or E6 of this section is subject to a fine or
penalty in accordance with title 13 of this Code and removal from the permit
parking waiting list.
      3.   Parking fees shall be as set forth in this subsection:
         a.   Permit Parking Lots: A minimum amount of one hundred twenty
dollars ($120.00) per calendar quarter will be charged for permit holders.
         b.   Daily Fee Parking Lots: Two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per day
or increases as determined by the Village Finance and Administrative Committee
and a not to exceed amount of ten dollars ($10.00) daily.
         c.   Night Parking: Parking between the hours of four o'clock (4:00)
P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. shall be permitted in public parking lots. No
vehicle bearing a State C class registration or higher or any recreational
vehicle is permitted to utilize night parking as stipulated in this subsection
E3c.
      4.   It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place or situate a
vehicle in a reserved or fee parking lot owned, leased or controlled by the
Village for the storage of a motor vehicle or motor vehicles; and it shall be
unlawful for any person to in any way utilize any parking permit issued by the
Village of Winfield for the storage of motor vehicle or motor vehicles.
"Storage" is defined as the continuous presence of a motor vehicle in a
reserved or fee parking lot, owned, leased or controlled by the Village for a
period of seventy two (72) hours or longer. Any person found guilty of
violating this subsection shall be ineligible for any reserved parking permit
for a period of one year from the date of the finding of guilty.
      5.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, change, alter,
duplicate or transfer any parking permit issued pursuant to this chapter.
      6.   It shall be unlawful to share or lend a Village parking permit to
another whom was not originally issued the permit. Permits are issued to one
holder and may not be shared. The name associated with the permit displayed
must match the name on the vehicle registration. Any person convicted of any of
these violations is subject to a fine of title 13 of this Code and the Village
Manager shall have the authority to revoke any such permit, or renewal thereof,
to any permit holder who pleads guilty to, or is found guilty and is convicted
of more than three (3) violations of any of the provisions of this subsection
within any consecutive period of six (6) months.
      7.   Relief from application of subsection E2d(3) of this section shall
be available from the Village of Winfield Administration and Finance Committee
upon petition by the permit holder, to the Village Finance Director. The period
for which relief may be granted shall not exceed a cumulative period of two (2)
weeks in a calendar year. Notwithstanding provisions of this chapter to the
contrary, any person violating this subsection shall be subject to penalties
set forth under title 13 of this Code.
      8.   Notwithstanding the foregoing schedule of fines and penalties, any
person who removes any mark placed on a tire by a police officer or who parks
overtime on property owned, maintained or controlled by the Village of
Winfield, or who parks on private property without the consent of the owner, or
who interferes with, damages, removes, tampers with, disables a vehicle wheel
lock, or who parks a commercial vehicle in violation of subsection E3c of this
section, shall be fined in accordance with section
13-1-4 of this Code.
      9.   The Village reserves the right to transfer all first or second party
user fees associated with a mobile parking app or a credit card transaction,
for the purposes of payment, to the responsibility of the user.
(Ord. 2015-05-13, 5-7-2015; amd. Ord. 2017-02-02, 2-16-2017; Ord. 2019-02-01,
2-7-2019; Ord. 2025-03-03, 3-20-2025)
ARTICLE A. PARKING METERS AND PARKING BOXES
SECTION:
6-2A-1: Definitions
6-2A-2: General Parking Regulations In Meter And Box Zones
6-2A-3: Parking Time Limitations
6-2A-4: Prohibited Acts; Use Of Slugs
6-2A-5: Penalty
6-2A-1: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
PARKING BOX ZONE: Any area where a parking box (a receptacle provided by the
Village for the deposit of money to pay for the privilege of parking in the
parking box zone) is installed or directed to be installed by the Board of
Trustees.
PARKING METER ZONE: Any area where parking meters are installed or directed to
be installed by order of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 655, 2-23-1984)
6-2A-2: GENERAL PARKING REGULATIONS IN METER AND BOX ZONES:
It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle in a parking meter zone or parking box
zone as established by order of the Board of Trustees, except as hereinafter
provided. The Board of Trustees shall, by order, designate the hours of the day
and the days of the year when parking in a parking meter zone or parking box
zone is permitted without compliance with the provisions of this article. Each
parking meter or box shall bear thereon a legend indicating the days and hours
when the requirement to deposit money therein shall apply. (Ord. 655, 2-23-
1984)
6-2A-3: PARKING TIME LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Time limitations for parking in parking meter zones shall be
established from time to time by the Board of Trustees. Parking fees in parking
meter zones shall be established by the Board of Trustees; the parking rate for
spaces in daily parking lots is set at two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per day,
effective June 1, 2010. (Ord. 2010-04-11, 4-15-2010)
   B.   It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle in a parking meter or parking
box zone for a period of time longer than is designated on the meter or box for
the value of the money deposited in such meter or box. (Ord. 655, 2-23-1984)
6-2A-4: PROHIBITED ACTS; USE OF SLUGS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to insert, or attempt to insert,
into the coin receptacle of any parking meter or box any slug, button or other
object, or to manipulate or operate, or attempt to manipulate or operate in any
manner whatever, any parking meter or box or any mechanism or device connected
or commonly used therewith with the intent to park in a parking meter zone
without paying therefor.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to insert, or to attempt to insert,
into the coin receptacle of any parking meter or box any slug, button, wire
hook or other implement or substance with the intent to obtain from such coin
receptacle any object theretofore deposited. (Ord. 655, 2-23-1984)
6-2A-5: PENALTY:
Any person accused of violating or failure to comply with the provisions of
this article shall be subject to the penalty provided in section
13-1-3 of this Code. (Ord. 2019-02-01, 2-7-2019)

   B.   Temporary Stop Intersections: For purposes of this section, a
"temporary stop intersection" is an intersection where a "Stop" sign is
activated by the Chief of Police or his designee during certain peak periods of
use in order to indicate that traffic shall stop at said intersection during
the times set forth hereinafter. The following are temporary stop
intersections:
 
Church Street Temporary stop for Beecher before and after school, church
              services, funerals, etc., at St. John's Church.

   A.   Alleys: It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle in any alley at
a speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour.
   B.   Highways Outside Urban Districts: It shall be unlawful to drive any
vehicle on any highway outside the urban district at speeds of more than fifty
five (55) miles per hour.
   C.   Towing Vehicles: It shall be unlawful to drive any vehicle of the first
division towing another vehicle, outside of an urban district more than fifty
five (55) miles per hour, in an urban district at more than twenty five (25)
miles per hour, or in an alley at not more than fifteen (15) miles per hour.
   D.   Specific Speed Restrictions: It shall be unlawful to drive any motor
vehicle on any street which is both within the corporate limits of the village
and under the maintenance jurisdiction of the village in excess of twenty five
(25) miles per hour except for the following streets, and as to those streets,
it shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle in excess of the speed
hereinafter specified: (Ord. 93-1-1, 1-14-1993)

   E.   Compliance With Posted Speed Limits: It shall be unlawful to drive any
vehicle on any street or highway within the village under the jurisdiction of
the state department of public works and buildings or of the county, at a speed
in excess of the posted speed limits.
   F.   Use Due Care: The fact that the speed of a vehicle does not exceed the
applicable maximum speed limit does not relieve the driver from the duty to
decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching
and going around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any
narrow or winding roadway or when special hazards exist with respect to
pedestrians or other traffic by reason of weather or highway conditions; and
speed shall be decreased as may be reasonably necessary to avoid colliding with
any person or vehicle on or entering the highway in compliance with legal
requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care.
   G.   Second Division Vehicles: Provided further that the speed of all
vehicles of the second division as defined by statute shall be as follows:
      1.   If the vehicle is designed and used for pulling freight and has a
gross weight of eight thousand (8,000) pounds or less (including the weight of
the vehicle and maximum load), and is equipped with pneumatic tires, the
maximum is fifty five (55) miles per hour outside of an urban district, twenty
five (25) miles per hour in an urban district, and fifteen (15) miles per hour
in an alley; but if such vehicle is equipped with two (2) or more solid tires,
the maximum is ten (10) miles per hour at all times and in all locations.
      2.   If the vehicle is designed and used for carrying more than seven (7)
passengers, and is equipped with pneumatic tires, the maximum is fifty five
(55) miles per hour. (Ord. 93-1-1, 1-14-1993)
