onto adjacent property.
STORMWATER FACILITIES: Includes, but is not limited to, such items as paved
gutters, surface inlets to subsurface storm drains, formed drainage swales,
riprap lined channels, catch basins or manholes that connect into a subsurface
drainage system, storm sewer and stormwater detention or retention facilities
with all to be located within a dedicated easement for stormwater drainage or
within publicly owned property.
STRUCTURE: A combination of materials used to form a construction that is safe
and stable including, but not limited to, buildings, stadiums, reviewing
stands, platforms, stagings, radio towers, bridges, trestles, sheds, shelters,
fences and display signs. The term "structure" shall be construed as if
followed by the words "or part thereof".
WATERCOURSE OR WATERWAY: A natural path in a lower area of the land that
carries natural stormwater runoff from areas of higher elevation. (Ord. 692, 7-
18-1985)
9-1A-2: GRADING PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: No structure shall be erected, moved or substantially
improved or parcel of land filled or excavated within the village without first
obtaining a grading permit. A grading permit will be required and shall
necessitate the submission of grading plans. The grading plans must be approved
by the village and a grading permit issued by the village before the following
activities can commence:
      1.   Construction of a new structure in a subdivision or planned unit
development where an overall grading plan has been approved by the corporate
authorities or a parcel is subject to said overall grading plan.
      2.   Construction of a new structure in an established subdivision or
planned unit development that does not have an approved overall grading plan.
      3.   Structure being moved where a parcel is affected by a structure
being moved, including the parcels from which the structure is moved and the
parcel to which it is being moved.
      4.   Parcel filled or excavated and all parcels affected by fill or
excavation or grading that will have an effect on other parcels.
      5.   The damming, altering, obstructing or the changing of natural
terrain or a waterway or watercourse carrying natural drainage from upstream
property.
      6.   Any change to an existing structure or an addition or alteration to
an existing structure that could affect stormwater drainage to the parcel being
improved or to the adjoining property. (Ord. 692, 7-18-1985)
   B.   Review And Inspection Fees: It is the obligation of the applicant
filing any application as herein described to pay all administrative and
professional consulting fees incurred by the village in processing and acting
upon such application. The deposit for those fees and expenses as hereinafter
set forth is intended to ensure to the village that adequate funds will be
available to the village to pay those fees and expenses, but the deposit
required is based upon an estimate only of what those fees may be and by making
the deposit the applicant is not relieved of the obligation to pay those fees
in full if in fact those fees and expenses exceed the deposit amount.
      1.   Single-Family Parcels:
         a.   Standard Parcels: The deposit for a grading permit for standard
parcels shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00) and a ten percent (10%)
administrative fee for handling. All costs for providing grading plans, grading
surveys or any other material required to be furnished by this article shall be
underwritten by the permittee at permittee's expense.
         b.   Critical Parcels: The deposit for a grading permit for critical
parcels shall be one thousand six hundred dollars ($1,600.00) and a ten percent
(10%) administrative fee for handling. All costs for providing grading plans,
grading surveys or any other material required to be furnished by this article
shall be underwritten by the permittee at the permittee's sole expense.
      2.   Other Than Single-Family Parcels: For all parcels other than single-
family parcels, the deposit for a grading permit shall be one thousand six
hundred dollars ($1,600.00) and a ten percent (10%) administrative fee for
handling costs for all services rendered by the village's consultants
pertaining to the parcel for which an application for a grading permit and the
issuance of a grading permit is being considered. The costs for consultants'
services shall include, but not be limited to, the costs for the providing of
services by the engineer for the village, planner for the village or other
consultants for the review of the material required by this article as well as
on site construction observation as well as any other services deemed necessary
by the village. All costs incurred by the village resulting from the rendering
of services by village consultants in relationship to this article shall be
paid for by permittee. (Ord. 2006-9-41, 9-7-2006)
   C.   Issuance Of Permit: The code enforcement official will be responsible
for issuance of all grading permits and shall be responsible for the
administration of this article. (Ord. 692, 7-18-1985; amd. 1994 Code)
   D.   Expiration Of Permit; Special Grading Permit:
      1.   Every grading permit shall expire by limitation and shall become
null and void if the work authorized by such permit has not begun within ninety
(90) days from the date of issuance therefor. In the case of such expiration
and cancellation, the code enforcement official shall provide written notice
thereof to the permittee.
      2.   If the work described in the grading permit has not been
substantially completed within one year of the date of issuance thereof, said
permit shall be expired and be canceled by the code enforcement official and
written notice thereof shall be given to the permittee together with a notice
that further work is prohibited; and no work shall proceed on the canceled
permit until a special grading permit has been issued by the village.
At the discretion of the code enforcement official, such special grading permit
may be issued based on the original application and permit, or the code
enforcement official may require submission of a new application. The special
grading permit may include limitations on time allowed for substantial
completion of the work. All special grading permits shall be accompanied by a
reasonable performance bond in an amount and form satisfactory to the village.
Said performance bond shall provide surety for the completion of the
improvements covered by the permit within the time limit set by the code
enforcement official.
   E.   Exemptions From Permit Requirements: A grading permit may not be
required on certain improvements under the following classifications: change to
an existing structure, an addition or alteration to an existing structure,
which changes, additions or alterations do not affect stormwater drainage to
the parcel in question, or do not affect stormwater drainage to adjoining
property as determined by the code enforcement official. (Ord. 692, 7-18-1985)
   F.   Obligation Of Responsible Party:
      1.   The application for a project subject to this article shall identify
the party responsible (hereinafter referred to as the responsible party) for
the application and any financial obligations set forth by this section,
including the name, address, daytime telephone number; relationship to the
project; and consent of the owner (if different).
      2.   It is the obligation of the responsible party filing any application
as herein described to pay all administrative, professional consulting fees and
public hearing expenses, including court reporter fees, incurred by the village
in processing and acting upon such application.
      3.   The deposit for those fees and expenses as hereinafter set forth is
intended to ensure that adequate funds will be available to the village to pay
those fees and expenses, and by making the deposit the applicant is not
relieved of the obligation to pay those fees in full if in fact those fees and
expenses exceed the deposit amount that may be with the village at any given
time. The village board shall establish the amount of the deposit to cover the
above noted costs by ordinance.
      4.   The village shall invoice the responsible party for any payment
obligation as set forth above and any deposit replenishment as may be required.
      5.   In the event that the responsible party fails to satisfy their
payment obligation and/or replenish their deposit balance within sixty (60)
days of receipt of an invoice from the village, a penalty in the amount of ten
percent (10%) of the original deposit requirement shall be added to the
outstanding obligation amount for each thirty (30) day period or portion
thereof that the responsible party's obligation remains delinquent. The village
shall retain the penalty payment amount.
   G.   Agreement To Pay Village Fees In Full: Before any application for which
a deposit fee is required by this section is accepted by the village or acted
upon, the responsible party will be required to acknowledge in writing the
responsible party's obligation to pay all fees pursuant to the provisions
contained within this section. Said form of acknowledgment shall be prescribed
by the village attorney and kept on file in the office of the village clerk.
   H.   Refunds And Additional Payments: The foregoing fee schedule is based
upon an estimate of the costs and fees that will be incurred by the village in
reviewing and acting upon the applications described. Accordingly, at the time
of final action by the corporate authorities or the written request by the
applicant that further action on the application terminate, an itemization of
costs for consultants and an administrative fee in the amount of ten percent
(10%) of the consultant's fee shall be sent to the petitioner either indicating
payment in full, providing a refund to the applicant or billing the applicant
an additional amount to be paid to the village by the applicant before final
action on the application is taken. All inspection, review and other fees
indicated by other ordinances shall remain applicable.
   I.   Additional Deposit Required: If, during the course of the review of an
application, the fees on deposit with the village reach a level of less than
fifty percent (50%) of the value of the initial deposit, the responsible party
shall pay to the village an amount that brings the deposit balance back to one
hundred percent (100%) of the initial deposit, and if the village provides the
applicant with an estimate in writing of the additional consultant fees that
will be incurred by the village, based upon estimates from the consultants
themselves, which shall be made available to the applicant, it is the
obligation of the applicant to pay to the village an additional deposit to
cover the cost of those additional anticipated fees plus an additional
administrative fee in the amount of ten percent (10%) of those anticipated
additional consultant fees. The village reserves the right to delay any further
action on the application until this additional deposit is paid. This
additional deposit is based upon an estimate of what those additional fees may
be and by making the additional deposit, the applicant is not relieved of his
obligation to pay those fees in full if in fact they exceed that estimate and
additional administrative fee. The provisions of subsection H of this section
with respect to a refund of any excess deposit shall then apply at the time of
final action or withdrawal as described in subsection H of this section. If the
additional payment is also exhausted prior to final action or withdrawal, then
an additional deposit shall again be required in accordance with the provisions
of this subsection. (Ord. 2007-2-8, 2-15-2007, amd. Ord. 2020-08-21, 8-20-2020)
9-1A-3: ISSUANCE OF BUILDING PERMIT:
No building permit shall be issued without a concurrent application for the
issuance of a grading permit. In the case of an internal building change, that
is a change occurring completely within a building, or as provided in
subsection 9-1A-2E of this article, a grading permit will not be required. The
issuance of a building permit and the grading permit shall be concurrent. (Ord.
692, 7-18-1985)
9-1A-4: GRADING PLANS:
   A.   Contents: Any grading plan submitted pursuant to the requirements of
this article shall contain the following information:
      1.   Foundation elevation, including the top of foundation and any
openings below top of the foundation on all new or existing structures or
portions thereof.
      2.   Site drainage showing the existing and proposed grades for a
particular parcel and for adjoining properties affected with a minimum of one
foot (1') contour intervals in sufficient detail to clearly indicate drainage
flows.
      3.   The parcel drainage shall be designed to flow away from the top of
the foundations. Stormwater being directed to the side yard of the parcel shall
be directed into a formed drainage swale, having a minimum slope of two percent
(2%) and a maximum slope of five percent (5%). In the event that conditions
dictate that some parts of the lot be higher than the structure foundation, the
grading must show specific drainage configurations for the parcel specifying
that all drainage is to be directed to flow away from the foundation.
      4.   Construction and work such as walkways, driveways, landscaping or
any structure shall be installed so that the construction of same will not
interfere with drainage. All sidewalks, driveways, patios and other flat work
shall be at an elevation relative to the foundation wall so that water will
drain away from the structure on all sides and off the lot in a manner which
will provide reasonable freedom from erosion and permanently pocketed surface
water.
      5.   The flow from off site tributary areas that are tributary to an
intermittent stream or overflow route that must pass through the parcel must be
identified on the grading plan and must be designed in such a way to adequately
handle the flow of all water to accommodate a 100-year storm frequency.
      6.   All overflow routes for the 100-year storm and for accumulated
stormwater runoff from several lots or from off site catchment areas must be
clearly designated on the grading plan with the total width of the flow route
contained within an easement for drainage purposes.
   B.   Nonconformity With Approved Grading Plans: Any deviation from the
approved grading plans as attached to the grading permit shall require the
following: the submission of a grading plan indicating what changes are
necessary as a result of the noncompliance with the approved grading plans. The
revised grading plan application shall include the same information as required
in the case of application for the original grading permit. All work on the
parcel shall terminate until such time as new grading plans are submitted by
the permittee and approved by the village. All persons aggrieved by a decision
or decisions of the code enforcement official shall have the right of appeal to
the village board of trustees by serving seven (7) days' written notice on the
board of trustees. A public hearing on the appeal shall be conducted with
notice given to adjoining property owners in all cases involving appeals that
may have a substantial adverse effect on adjoining property. (Ord. 692, 7-18-
1985)
9-1A-5: STORMWATER MANAGEMENT FACILITIES:
   A.   All stormwater management facilities within any development must be
constructed in accordance with the plans provided by the permittee's design
engineer and approved by the engineer for the village. The design drawings must
be certified by a registered professional engineer and provided on standard
twenty four inch by thirty six inch (24" x 36") sheets. Smaller individual
parcels may be submitted on a smaller appropriate size.
   B.   During the review process by the village, the engineer for the village
shall designate each parcel within any subdivision or planned unit development
as critical or standard. (Ord. 692, 7-18-1985)
9-1A-6: EASEMENTS:
Whenever a natural watercourse, waterway, drainage swale or the like, draining
five (5) tributary acres or more, crosses through a parcel or any part of a
parcel, a drainage easement will be required before a grading permit or a
building permit will be issued. The engineer for the village will verify the
total tributary area draining through the subject parcel or part thereof, and
the expected runoff to determine the required capacity of the natural
watercourse and make recommendations on size of permanent easements. (Ord. 692,
7-18-1985)
9-1A-7: GRADING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Subdivisions And Planned Unit Developments:
      1.   General Requirements: In a subdivision or a planned unit
development, all rough grading within a given block or area must be completed
prior to the issuance of any building permits. The developer, through its
project engineer, shall certify in writing that all rough grading is complete
within a given block, watershed or other area in strict conformity with the
grading plan as prepared and approved by the village. The engineer for the
village shall verify grading is complete as required and so notify the village
before building can proceed. All proposed drainageways, swales, detention
facilities, lot and block grading shall be complete to ensure minimum effect
and disturbance upon properties adjoining said development or other portions
within the development.
      2.   Critical Parcels:
         a.   Those parcels designated as "critical" within said development
shall have a building spot survey performed immediately after the foundation
has been poured and backfilled to ensure compliance with building setback
requirements and to ensure that elevations of any openings in the foundation
are in conformance with the approved grading plan requirements of high water
restrictions as they relate to the grading plan or stormwater management plan.
At the same time, the developer will ensure that the drainage pattern on a
particular parcel has not been altered during the course of the foundation
construction and backfilling so as to adversely affect the overall drainage
plan. Any improper grading deemed by the code enforcement official and/or
engineer for the village to be a potential hazard to any property shall be
corrected immediately upon his direction or shall be cause for suspension of
work on the parcel.
         b.   After the structure on a parcel is substantially completed and
final grading is completed, the developer shall furnish an occupancy survey to
certify that the final ground elevations are in strict compliance with the
elevations indicated on the approved grading plan.
         c.   The developer shall be responsible for the grading of each lot or
parcel through all stages of construction to ensure that drainage from
tributary areas is not blocked or hindered and that servient property is
protected from damage by providing proper grading to a storm drainage facility
in accordance with the approved grading plan.
      3.   Standard Parcels:
         a.   Those parcels designated as "standard" parcels within said
development shall have a building spot survey performed immediately after the
foundation has been poured and backfilled to ensure compliance with building
setback requirements and to ensure that rough grading has been substantially
completed so that all drainage flows away from the building to side yards,
front yards or rear yards in conformance with the approved grading plan. The
code enforcement official, or his designated representative, shall visually
inspect all standard parcels at the time rough grading is substantially
complete to ensure that yard areas have been rough graded properly before work
is allowed to continue beyond the foundation point.
         b.   After the structure on a parcel is substantially completed and
final grading is complete, the developer shall furnish an occupancy survey to
certify that final ground elevations are in strict compliance with the
elevations indicated on the approved grading plan.
      4.   Exceptions: In those cases where conditions, in the opinion of the
engineer for the village, do not permit compliance with the approved grading
plan, a revised grading plan must be submitted to the village in the same
detail as the original submission requires. In the case of those parcels that
need additional detail, the same shall be provided as required by the engineer
for the village.
   B.   Individual Lots Or Parcels Other Than In Planned Unit Developments:
Whenever an improvement, as described in subsection 9-1A-2A of this article, is
proposed on a parcel that is not part of a planned unit development or
subdivision with an overall grading plan, the engineer for the village shall
render an opinion to classify the subject parcel as a "critical" or "standard"
parcel.
      1.   Critical Parcels:
         a.   If a lot is designated as a "critical" parcel by the engineer for
the village, a grading plan will be required complying with subsection 9-1A-4A
of this article.
         b.   After the foundation has been poured, a building spot survey
shall be performed, indicating the location of the building with respect to
setback requirements, and to ensure that elevations of any openings in the
foundation are in conformance with the requirements of high water restrictions
recommended on the grading plan or stormwater management plan. Upon receipt of
the building spot survey, the code enforcement official will inspect the site
to ensure that natural overland flow has not been obstructed in any way that
may adversely affect the subject parcel, adjoining or adjacent parcels or
upstream parcels. If none of the foregoing conditions are observed by the code
enforcement official during his inspection, completion of the structure may
commence.
         c.   Upon substantial completion of the structure and final grading of
the parcel, the owner shall furnish an occupancy survey to certify the final
ground elevations and drainage contours are in strict compliance with the
elevations indicated on the approved grading plan.
      2.   Standard Parcels:
         a.   Those lots or parcels designated as "standard" parcels with
proposed improvements consisting of those described in subsection 9-1A-2A of
this article will be required to have a grading permit.
         b.   After the foundation has been completed, a building spot survey
shall be performed to ensure compliance with building setback requirements and
approved grading plan. Also at that time, the code enforcement official, or his
representative, shall visually inspect the site to ensure that the yard areas
have been graded, smoothed and sloped to facilitate drainage away from the
building and to front or rear yard stormwater facilities.
         c.   After the structure on the parcel has been substantially
completed, the code enforcement official will reinspect the site to determine
if the final grading has been provided in substantial conformance with the
approved grading plan. No occupancy permit will be issued unless and until
final grading has been provided in compliance with the approved grading plan.
(Ord. 692, 7-18-1985)
9-1A-8: PROTECTIVE GROUND COVER:
   A.   General Requirements: Immediately after final grading has been
accomplished and approved by the village on all parcels, protective ground
cover shall be installed on the parcel including the parkway for which the
permit was issued. All permittees shall be required to install protective
ground cover on all parcels for which a grading permit has been issued. The
protective ground cover shall be installed within the growing season in which
the occupancy permit is to be issued. If weather does not permit the
installation of protective ground cover, a cash bond in an amount sufficient to
guarantee the completion of the installation of the protective ground cover
shall be furnished; however, in no case shall the completion of the
installation of protective ground cover be more than the current growing
season, or June 15 of the next growing season. Alternative protective ground
cover other than grass or sod must secure the approval of the code enforcement
official at the time the grading plan is reviewed or prior to the time an
occupancy permit is requested if the permittee desires to change same.
Suggested seeding mixtures, application rates, seeding periods and areas of
application for establishing permanent protective ground cover are set forth in
table 1, on file with the village.
   B.   Specifications:
      1.   Seeded Areas: All portions of the parcel not having pavement,
sidewalks or other similar type materials placed thereon are to be provided
with protective ground cover. If the protective ground cover is seed, the
following suggestions are made in preparing the area for seed:
         a.   Place topsoil on area to be graded an average depth of four
inches (4") and grade as required to finished grades established on the grading
plan.
         b.   Prepare a firm seedbed free of clods or stones.
         c.   Apply fertilizer in sufficient rates of application to establish
satisfactory growth in the seeded area.
         d.   Select a suitable seeding mixture that will produce a permanent
ground cover within a reasonable time.
         e.   Broadcast the seed uniformly over the parcel.
         f.   Apply a mulch on all sites where slopes exceed ten feet (10') in
length and where slopes are steeper than four feet (4') horizontal to one foot
(1') vertical.
         g.   On grassed waterways where sod is not used, a fibrous or
synthetic erosion control netting shall be applied. The fibrous or synthetic
erosion control netting shall be secured with six inch (6") long metal staples
or no. 8 wire along all edges at twelve inches (12") on center. All joints are
to overlap in the netting a minimum of four inches (4") and be secured with
staples a minimum of four inches (4") apart.
      2.   Sodded Areas: Where protective ground cover is to consist of sod, it
is suggested the permanent lawn areas to be sodded be prepared in the following
manner:
         a.   All areas shall be provided with adequate topsoil having an
average thickness of four inches (4") and graded as required to finished grades
established on the grading plan. Topsoil shall be scarified as required.
         b.   A dense cultivated sod of bluegrass, bromegrass or fescue shall
be installed. Only moist, fresh sod shall be used.
         c.   Sod should be installed in spring or fall or as moisture
requirements are met and when the ground is not frozen.
         d.   Sufficient irrigation shall be provided to ensure the growth for
the newly installed sod. The obligation to furnish irrigation when sprinkling
restrictions are in effect remains the responsibility of the permittee.
   C.   Approval Of Ground Cover: The Code enforcement official may approve a
ground cover of a substance other than grass as long as the ground cover
maintains the proposed stormwater runoff capabilities of the area to be so
landscaped in substantial conformity with the degree of ground cover that would
be accomplished if grass were installed and as long as the substance other than
grass is not injurious to the health, safety and welfare of the surrounding
residents. (Ord. 692, 7-18-1985)
9-1A-9: OCCUPANCY SURVEY AND PERMITS:
   A.   Occupancy Survey: Immediately after the final parcel grading has been
accomplished, but before final seeding, sodding or landscaping takes place, the
permittee shall conduct an occupancy survey to determine if the grading has
been done in conformity with the approved grading plan. Said occupancy survey
must be submitted and approved by the Village prior to the issuance of a final
occupancy permit.
   B.   Occupancy Permits:
      1.   Conditional Occupancy Permit:
         a.   If a parcel cannot be final graded because of adverse weather
conditions or other conditions beyond the control of the permittee, the Code
enforcement official may issue a conditional occupancy permit. The conditional
occupancy permit shall be effective for only the reasonable number of days
sufficient to sustain the adverse weather conditions or the other conditions
that were beyond the permittee's control. In those instances where a
conditional occupancy permit is to be issued, the permittee shall furnish a
cash bond in an amount sufficient to guarantee the installation and successful
growth of the protective ground cover. In no case shall the cash bond be in
excess of the total cost to the Village to have the work done by an outside
contractor.
         b.   At the time of the issuance of a conditional occupancy permit,
the permittee, builder or owner shall sign a document informing them of the
provisions necessary to obtain a final occupancy permit. The document referred
to herein shall be signed by the permittee, builder and owner prior to the time
the conditional occupancy permit is issued. At the time of application for a
conditional occupancy permit, the Code enforcement official shall determine the
reasonable number of days for permittee's compliance with the requirements of a
final occupancy permit based upon the weather conditions or other conditions
that made the issuance of a final occupancy unreasonable because of said
conditions.
      2.   Final Occupancy Permit: Upon completion of final grading and the
installation of protective ground cover in substantial conformity with the
approved plans, a final occupancy permit shall be issued to the holder of the
grading permit; however, in those cases where nonconformity with the Village
ordinances do not permit the issuance of a final occupancy permit, said permit
shall not be issued. Determination of conformity with the approved grading
plans shall be made by the Village Code enforcement official. (Ord. 692, 7-18-
1985)
9-1A-10: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any portion of this article shall, upon
conviction, be fined as provided in section
13-1-4 of this Code for each offense. Each day such violation shall continue
shall constitute a separate offense subjecting any offender to a separate and
additional fine. (Ord. 2019-02-01, 2-7-2019)
ARTICLE B. CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION
SECTION:
9-1B-1: Definitions
9-1B-2: Required
9-1B-3: Application
9-1B-4: Fees And Bonds
9-1B-5: Liability Insurance Required
9-1B-6: Issuance
9-1B-7: Scope Of General Contractor's Registration
9-1B-8: General Duties Of Registrants
9-1B-9: Suspension Or Revocation; Reinstatement
9-1B-10: Penalty
9-1B-11: Severability
9-1B-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires:
CONTRACTOR: Any person, partnership, corporation or other business entity
engaged in the business of constructing, altering or repairing buildings or
other structures or lots and all trades and crafts associated with such work
within the village of Winfield, for which a building permit is required by this
chapter, including, but not restricted to, general building contractors,
excavating contractors, cement or concrete contractors, masonry contractors,
carpentry contractors, roofing, heating, air conditioning, ventilating,
mechanical and electrical contractors and subcontractors. A homeowner engaged
in altering or repairing their personal residence or lot shall not be
considered a contractor for purpose of this article. A homeowner constructing a
stand alone structure or addition to an existing building that will serve as a
part of their personal residence, which is in excess of eight hundred (800)
square feet in area is required to register as a contractor, and shall be
subject to the bonding requirements as set forth in subsection 9-1B-4C, "Bonds;
Letter Of Credit", of this article, but shall be exempted from paying the
registration fee.
GENERAL CONTRACTOR: A person, partnership, corporation or other business entity
that uses one or more trades or subcontractors to perform the required
construction on any project for which a building permit is required.
HOMEOWNER: The owner-occupant of a parcel located within the village of
Winfield who is listed as the owner on the township assessor's parcel tax roll
or is confirmed as an owner by village staff through the presentation of a
recorded deed or copy of a contract for the purchase of said parcel located
within the village of Winfield.
SUBCONTRACTOR: A contractor who performs only one type of work that is
classified as a trade, such as excavating contractors, cement or concrete
contractors, masonry contractors, carpentry contractors, roofing, heating, air
conditioning, ventilating, refrigeration, mechanical and electrical
contractors. (Ord. 2006-10-47, 10-5-2006)
9-1B-2: REQUIRED:
No person shall act or perform any services as a general contractor, contractor
or subcontractor within the village of Winfield without first having obtained a
contractor's registration therefor as herein provided.
   A.   Contractors that hold a valid state of Illinois plumbing license and
who perform plumbing or irrigation work only are not required to register under
this article to perform said work in the village of Winfield; however, they
must comply with all village permit and inspection requirements.
   B.   An electrical or heating, ventilating, air conditioning or
refrigeration contractor, upon submission of sufficient proof of valid current
licensing as an electrical or heating, ventilation, air conditioning or
refrigeration contractor or subcontractor with another Illinois municipality as
determined by the village of Winfield, does not need to register with the
village of Winfield as a contractor or subcontractor. (Ord. 2006-10-47, 10-5-
2006)
9-1B-3: APPLICATION:
All applications for contractor's registration required in section
9-1B-2 of this article shall be made in writing to the village of Winfield,
department of building, upon forms furnished by the village. Each application
shall state the name and business address of the applicant, whether it is a
general contractor, contractor or subcontractor, and if a contractor or
subcontractor, the trade or trades involved, the number of the applicant's
employees who would be operating under such registration and a statement that
the applicant is familiar with all applicable village of Winfield ordinances,
codes and regulations and agrees to fully comply with same. (Ord. 2006-1-01, 1-
5-2006)
9-1B-4: FEES AND BONDS:
   A.   Registration Forms: The village manager shall be charged with
promulgating the necessary contractor registration forms and other
administrative provisions necessary to implement this article.
   B.   Registration Fees: The annual fees for a contractor's registration, as
required in section
9-1B-2 of this article are as follows:
      1.   General contractor registration fee:
         a.   Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year for businesses;
         b.   Fees for applications received after July 31 shall be prorated by
one-half (1/2).
      2.   Subcontractor and all other contractors' registration fee: One
hundred dollars ($100.00) per year, except the following:
         a.   Electrical contractor or subcontractor: Twenty five dollars
($25.00).
         b.   Heating, ventilating, air conditioning, and refrigeration
contractors or subcontractors: Forty dollars ($40.00).
         c.   Fees for applications received after July 31 shall be prorated by
one-half (1/2).
   C.   Bonds; Letter Of Credit: Each applicant for a registration shall,
before receiving such a registration, file with the village of Winfield
building department an indemnifying bond issued by a company approved and
authorized to issue bonds by the state of Illinois in a form suitable to the
village of Winfield in the following penal sums payable to the village of
Winfield. If a property owner that is serving as a general contractor cannot
secure bonding, a letter of credit that can be drawn upon by the village or
cash bond can be substituted.
      1.   Twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for a general contractor, and
      2.   Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for a contractor or subcontractor;
including property owners serving as their own contractor.
   D.   Proof Of State Licensure: All roofing, plumbing, or electrical
contractors or subcontractors shall submit sufficient proof as determined by
the village of Winfield of valid current licensing as a roofing, plumbing or
electrical contractor by the state of Illinois or another Illinois municipality
that performs licensure. (Ord. 2006-10-47, 10-5-2006)
9-1B-5: LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall act as a general contractor, contractor or subcontractor within
the village, nor shall be registered, unless said general contractor,
contractor or subcontractor deposits with the village of Winfield a certificate
of insurance issued to said general contractor, contractor or subcontractor by
a company approved and authorized to issue such insurance by the state of
Illinois for the full period of the registration period in the following
amounts with aggregate liability insurance limits required in the following
minimum levels:
A. General contractor:
A. General contractor:
  General liability and or excess  $1,000,000.00 aggregate
   liability in combination
  Auto liability                   $500,000.00 per occurrence
  Workers' compensation            State of Illinois statutory minimum
                                     unless exempt
B. Property owner acting as own contractor; insurance coverage shall be
   job specific:
  General liability                $500,000.00 per occurrence
  Auto liability                   $500,000.00 per occurrence
C. Contractor or subcontractor, not including a business engaged in
   demolition work:
  General liability                $500,000.00 per occurrence
  Auto liability                   $500,000.00 per occurrence
  Workers' compensation            State of Illinois statutory minimum
                                     unless exempt
 
The certificate of insurance shall provide that the insurance is not cancelable
during the policy period without thirty (30) days' written notice to the
Village of Winfield, and the Village of Winfield shall be named as certificate
holder. Workers' compensation for any contractor or subcontractor who is a sole
proprietor or partnership, and not a corporation, need not have workers'
compensation insurance on the owner or partners unless they so elect. (Ord.
2006-10-47, 10-5-2006)
9-1B-6: ISSUANCE:
The Village of Winfield Department of Building shall issue registration upon
proper application and compliance with the provisions of this article, and
payment of the fee set forth in section
9-1B-4 of this article. All registration shall be valid until January 31 of the
year following issuance unless otherwise suspended or revoked. All annual
renewal registrations are due by January 31 of that calendar year. (Ord. 2006-
1-01, 1-5-2006)
9-1B-7: SCOPE OF GENERAL CONTRACTOR'S REGISTRATION:
Any person registered as a general contractor shall not be required to secure
an additional registration for performance of carpentry, masonry, cement or
concrete contracting. (Ord. 2006-1-01, 1-5-2006)
9-1B-8: GENERAL DUTIES OF REGISTRANTS:
All general contractors, contractors and subcontractors registered under
section
9-1B-2 of this article shall comply with the provisions of all applicable
Village Codes and ordinances and, in addition thereto, shall provide a refuse
container with a cover as necessary and, at least once each week or more often
as directed by the Village of Winfield building official, shall remove or cause
to be removed from the site of contractor's activities all trash, refuse and
waste materials. General contractors, contractors and subcontractors shall at
all times keep the site of activities in an orderly condition, free from
standing water, unguarded dangerous implements or conditions and health and
safety hazards, and contractors shall not obstruct traffic on streets or
sidewalks or permit dirt or waste materials to fall or be carried onto such
public ways. General contractors, contractors and subcontractors shall also
abide by the Village's Tree Preservation Ordinances and shall provide
applicable barriers around all trees as provided by this Code. (Ord. 2006-1-01,
1-5-2006)
9-1B-9: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION; REINSTATEMENT:
Any registration issued under the provisions of this article may be suspended
for up to thirty (30) days or revoked by the Village Manager or his/her
designee for any violation of any of the provisions of this article. The
Village Manager shall by certified mail or personal delivery provide the
registrant with a notice describing the violation(s) alleged and giving the
date, time and location of a hearing on said violation(s) before the Village
Manager or his/her designee. Such notice shall be mailed to or served on the
registrant at least five (5) days before the hearing. The Village Manager is
authorized to adopt such reasonable rules and regulations regarding the hearing
process as is necessary. Any suspension or revocation shall not preclude any
other remedies or actions authorized by law. No person whose registration has
been revoked as herein provided shall be eligible for a new registration for a
period of one year from the date of such revocation. All appeals from the
action of the Village Manager to revoke a contractor's registration shall be
subject to review by the Circuit Court of the State of Illinois as provided by
law.
The Village of Winfield may refuse to issue a registration that does not meet
all the requirements of this article. Any appeals from an action of the Village
of Winfield Building Department to refuse to issue a contractor's registration
shall be filed within ten (10) days of such refusal with the Village Manager
who shall conduct a hearing on such refusal to issue a registration in the same
manner as provided above for the suspension or revocation of a registration.
(Ord. 2006-1-01, 1-5-2006)
9-1B-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation performing work in the Village without having
a current valid registration shall be ordered to stop work in progress by the
Village Manager and/or his/her assignees until proper registration is obtained.
In addition to all other remedies available to the Village of Winfield at law
or equity, any contractor who violates or fails to comply with any of the
provisions of this article shall be fined as provided in section
13-1-4 of this Code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues. (Ord. 2019-02-01, 2-7-2019)
9-1B-11: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, paragraph, subdivision, clause, sentence or provision of this
article shall be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid,
such judgment shall not affect, impair, invalidate or nullify the remainder
thereof, which remainder shall remain and continue in full force and effect.
(Ord. 2006-1-01, 1-5-2006)
CHAPTER 2
EXISTING STRUCTURES CODE
(Rep. by Ord. 2016-12-28, 12-1-2016)
CHAPTER 3
SIGNS 1
SECTION:
9-3-1: Permit Requirements
9-3-2: Illuminated Signs
9-3-3: Inspections
9-3-4: Bond And Insurance
9-3-5: Liability For Signs
9-3-6: Dangerous Or Illegal Signs
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  10-2-16 of this code.
9-3-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required; Exemption: No sign shall be constructed, erected,
originally painted, converted, altered, rebuilt, enlarged, remodeled, relocated
or expanded until a permit for such sign has been obtained in accordance with
the standards and procedures set out in this chapter. However, no permit shall
be required for maintenance as defined herein.
   B.   Application For Permit: Application for permits shall be submitted on a
form and in the manner prescribed by the zoning administrator and shall contain
the following information:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
      2.   Location of building, structure or lot to which or upon which the
sign or other advertising structure is to be attached or erected.
      3.   Position of the sign or other advertising structure in relation to
nearby buildings or structures.
      4.   Two (2) drawings and one electronic version of the plans and
specifications and method of construction and attachment to the building or in
the ground.
      5.   At the discretion of the zoning administrator, copy of stress sheets
and calculations showing the structure is designed for dead load and wind
pressure in any direction in the amount required by this title and all other
ordinances of the village.
      6.   Name of person, firm, corporation or association erecting structure.
      7.   Written permission from the owner of the property upon which the
sign is to be located, if other than the applicant.
      8.   Such other information as the zoning administrator shall require to
show full compliance with this and all other laws and ordinances of the
village.
   C.   Permit Fees: Permit fees charged for each sign are found in section
9-1-4 of this title.
   D.   Expiration Of Permit: If the work authorized under a sign permit has
not been completed within six (6) months after the date of issuance, the permit
shall become null and void.
   E.   Permit Denial Or Revocation; Refusal Of Further Permit:
      1.   Denial, Suspension Or Revocation: The zoning administrator may deny,
suspend or revoke a permit issued under provisions of this chapter whenever the
permit is issued on the basis of a misstatement of fact or fraud. When a sign
permit is denied by the zoning administrator, he shall give written notice of
the denial to the applicant, together with a brief written statement of the
reasons for the denial.
      2.   Refusal Of Further Permits: The village shall refuse to issue any
further sign permit to any such party or owner, or their agents or
representatives, who is in violation of the requirements of this chapter or who
refuses to pay costs assessed for corrective action under the provisions of
this chapter.
   F.   Appeals: Appeals of the interpretation of this chapter by the zoning
administrator are heard by the zoning board of appeals, and all hearings and
determinations shall be subject to all provisions of the zoning code. (Ord.
2010-07-23, 7-15-2010)
9-3-2: ILLUMINATED SIGNS:
All illuminated signs shall be subject to the following requirements:
   A.   All electrical work on illuminated signs and signs with electrical
wiring must be covered by a valid electrical permit.
   B.   Relettering which requires a change of piping or sign wiring shall be
subject to the approval of the building inspector.
   C.   The voltage of any electrical apparatus used in connection with the
sign shall be conspicuously placed on that apparatus.
   D.   Illuminated signs shall not have any flashing, scintillating, traveling
or blinking lights or rotating beacons, nor shall any beam of light be
projected through a mechanism which periodically changes the color of the light
reaching the sign. A sign on which the current time or temperature, or both, is
indicated by intermittent lighting changes shall not be deemed to be a flashing
sign if the lights do not exceed forty (40) watts per lamp, the changes are
limited to the numerals indicating the time or temperature, and the sign is in
conformance with the other regulations for such signs in this chapter.
   E.   Whenever external illumination is used for a sign, the source of the
light shall be located, shielded and directed in such a manner that the light
does not shine or cause glare onto any surrounding public street or private
residence.
   F.   Internally illuminated signs shall permit light to shine fully through
only the lettering and graphic elements of the sign. The background for such
lettering and graphics shall be opaque or translucent and shall transmit light
at a level substantially less than that transmitted through the lettering and
graphics.
   G.   In no case shall the lighting intensity of any sign, whether resulting
from internal or external illumination, exceed seventy five (75) foot-candles
when measured with a standard light meter perpendicular to the face of the sign
at a distance equal to the narrowest dimension of the sign. (Ord. 2010-07-23,
7-15-2010)
9-3-3: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Preinstallation Inspection: The sign contractor shall schedule with the
zoning administrator a preinstallation inspection prior to installing any sign
requiring a permit. Such inspection shall include a footing inspection, if
applicable, and confirmation of the other details of mounting and placement.
   B.   Final Inspection: The sign contractor shall notify the zoning
administrator upon completion of the work for which a permit is required and so
schedule a final inspection by appropriate inspectors. (Ord. 2010-07-23, 7-15-
2010)
9-3-4: BOND AND INSURANCE:
   A.   Bond: For signs costing more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), a
performance bond on the work to be done shall be required at the time of
issuance of a sign permit. The amount of the bond shall be determined by a
schedule maintained by the zoning administrator with the approval of the
village board.
   B.   Insurance: Every sign contractor required to provide public
indemnification shall provide a certificate of insurance with coverage adequate
to indemnify the village against any form of liability to a minimum of five
hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). (Ord. 2010-07-23, 7-15-2010)
9-3-5: LIABILITY FOR SIGNS:
All sign contractors engaged in the erection, alteration, relocation,
maintenance of a sign or other sign work in or over or immediately adjacent to
a public right of way or public property so that a portion of the public right
of way or public property is used or encroached upon by the contractor, shall
agree to hold harmless and indemnify the village, its officers, agents and
employees from any and all claims of negligence resulting from such work. (Ord.
2010-07-23, 7-15-2010)
9-3-6: DANGEROUS OR ILLEGAL SIGNS:
   A.   Notice Of Dangerous Or Illegal Condition; Remedy: If the zoning
administrator shall at any time find that any sign is unsafe or insecure, or is
a menace to the public, or has been constructed, installed or is being
maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter, he shall give
written notice to the sign contractor (if the sign installation is incomplete
or improper), to the person to whom the sign permit had been issued or, if the
permittee cannot be located within thirty (30) days, to the owner of the
premises on which the sign is located. If the notified party fails to remove or
alter the sign so as to comply with the standards herein set forth within
fourteen (14) calendar days after notice, such sign may be removed, or altered
to comply, by the village.
   B.   Financial Liability: The cost of sign repair or removal performed on
privately owned signs at the order of the zoning administrator in conformance
with the provisions of this chapter shall be the joint and several liability of
the following:
      1.   The sign contractor, if the sign installation was improper or not
complete at the time notice of violation was given, and shall be collected from
his bond, or
      2.   The sign owner, or
      3.   If the sign owner cannot be located by the zoning administrator
within thirty (30) days, the premises owner.
   C.   Costs A Lien; Foreclosure: In the event of failure by any party to
reimburse the village within sixty (60) days for costs incurred for repair or
removal ordered by the zoning administrator, the village board shall certify
the charges for repair or removal to the village attorney who will be then
authorized to file a notice of lien in the appropriate office of the recorder
of deeds to foreclose this lien, and to sue the owner of the real estate, or
sign permittee, or their agents, in a civil action to recover the money due to
the foregoing services, plus all expenses, as hereinafter more fully described,
and reasonable attorney fees to be fixed by the court. Any such judgment shall
be enforced in accordance with the law. Included in the expenses recoverable by
the village, the village is entitled to collect the costs of filing the notice
of lien, foreclosing said lien and all litigation costs, together with all
office and legal expense incurred in connection with the collection of the
amount due hereunder. (Ord. 2010-07-23, 7-15-2010)
CHAPTER 4
HOUSE NUMBERING
SECTION:
9-4-1: House Numbering Plan
9-4-2: Plats Kept; Numbers Issued
9-4-3: Size Of Figures
9-4-4: Failure To Number
9-4-5: Changing Number
9-4-6: Penalty
9-4-1: HOUSE NUMBERING PLAN:
All buildings situated or hereafter erected or located on any of the streets,
avenues and public highways within the Village shall be numbered by the owner
or occupant thereof according to the following plan:
   A.   For the purpose of said numbering there are hereby established two (2)
base lines: a north and south base line coinciding with the east section line
of section 7 in Milton Township and an east and west base line coinciding with
the north section lines of section 13 and section 14 in Winfield Township and
the south section line of section 7 in Milton Township.
   B.   House numbers on the north and south streets, avenues and public
highways shall begin at the east and west base line, which is zero, the first
number north of said base line being known as 0 N 0 1, and the first number
south of said base line being known as 0 S 0 1, one number being allotted for
each fifteen feet (15') of frontage; provided, that house numbers south of
Roosevelt Road shall begin with 1 S 0 1.
   C.   House numbers on the east and west streets, avenues and public highways
shall begin with 26 W 0 1 west of the north and south base line, and with 27 W
0 1 at the east section lines of section 12, section 13 and section 24 in
Winfield Township, and with 28 W 0 1 at the east section lines of section 14
and section 23 in Winfield Township; one number likewise being allotted for
each fifteen feet (15') of frontage.
   D.   The numbers shall progress in the direction indicated, with each one-
eighth (1/8) of a mile being allotted one hundred (100) numbers or less. The
four hundred (400) block shall terminate at the quarter section lines in all
cases. In fractional sections one hundred (100) numbers shall be allotted to
each remaining one-eighth (1/8) of a mile.
   E.   Odd numbers shall be on the south and east sides of streets and even
numbers shall be on the north and west sides of streets.
   F.   By the term "east and west streets" as used herein, is meant all
streets the direction of which is easterly and westerly, and by the term "north
and south streets" as used herein, is meant all streets the direction of which
is northerly and southerly. (Ord. 299, 8-30-1963)
9-4-2: PLATS KEPT; NUMBERS ISSUED:
For the purpose of facilitating a correct enumeration, plats of all the
streets, avenues and public ways within the Village, showing the proper number
of all lots or houses fronting thereon, shall be prepared by the Village
Engineer and filed with the Village Clerk, and it shall be the duty of the
Village Clerk to assign to each house its proper number and deliver free of
charge to the owner or occupant a certificate designating each number, and to
adjust all mistakes and errors in numbering. No number shall be placed on any
premises except that contained in the certificate of the Clerk. (Ord. 299, 8-
30-1963)
9-4-3: SIZE OF FIGURES:
Each of the figures of every number shall be not less than three inches (3") in
height, of proportionate width, of such color and affixed in such place as to
be easily and distinctly read and in plain view from the street. Said numbers
shall be placed on the building either on, above or immediately to the side of
the door, or at some other and more conspicuous place on or near the front of
the building. (Ord. 299, 8-30-1963)
9-4-4: FAILURE TO NUMBER:
   A.   Any owner or occupant of any building now erected or located in the
Village who, after being notified in writing by mail by the Village Clerk that
the building number is on record and filed with the Village Clerk, shall, for
thirty (30) days after such written notice shall be mailed, neglect or refuse
to number any building owned or occupied by him in conformity with the
provisions of this chapter, shall be subject to a fine as provided in section
13-1-3 of this Code.
   B.   Any owner or occupant of any building hereafter erected in the Village
who shall, for thirty (30) days after the same shall be erected, neglect or
refuse to number said building according to the provisions of this chapter,
shall be subject to a fine as provided in section
13-1-3 of this Code. (Ord. 299, 8-30-1963; amd. 1994 Code; per correspondence
dated 7-31-2018)
9-4-5: CHANGING NUMBER:
Whenever any premises have been numbered as herein provided, it shall be
unlawful for any person or corporation to change or alter such number or to
place any other number thereon except that contained in the certificate of the
Village Clerk. (Ord. 299, 8-30-1963)
9-4-6: PENALTY:
Any owner or occupant of any building now situated or hereafter erected in the
Village who shall number said building without having first obtained from the
Village Clerk a certificate designating the proper number or who shall change
or alter any such number or place any other number thereon except that
contained in the certificate of the Village Clerk, or who shall violate any of
the provisions of this chapter for which violation no fine has been above
provided, shall be subject to a fine as provided in section
13-1-3 of this Code. (Ord. 299, 8-30-1963; amd. 1994 Code; per correspondence
dated 7-31-2018)
CHAPTER 5
FENCES
SECTION:
9-5-1: Definitions
9-5-2: Permit Required; Fees
9-5-3: Fence Requirements
9-5-3-1: Residential Districts
9-5-4: Prohibited Fences
9-5-5: Nonconforming Fences
9-5-6: Penalties
9-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
BUILDING LINE: The line described by the side of the principal building closest
to the adjoining lot line.
DECORATIVE FENCE: Any fence not in excess of forty two inches (42") in height
constructed of wrought iron, split rails or pickets which does not totally
enclose a yard.
GARDEN FENCE: Any fence not exceeding four feet (4'), designed to enclose a
garden for the purposes of protecting vegetables and plants.
LANDSCAPE FENCE: Any fence that does not totally enclose an area and is not
more than twenty feet (20') in total length measured by adding together the
length of the fence in each direction that it extends not more than ten feet
(10') in length in any one direction.
LOT LINE AND CORNER LOT: As defined in the Winfield Zoning Ordinance, section
10-1-4 of this Code.
MAJOR ARTERIAL HIGHWAY: A highway with four (4) or more lanes of traffic and an
average traffic volume in excess of fifteen thousand (15,000) vehicles per
twenty four (24) hours and a speed limit of forty (40) miles per hour. (Ord.
671, 8-22-1984; amd. Ord. 91-10-4; 1994 Code)
9-5-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEES:
A permit is required for the construction, installation or erection of all
fences except landscape and garden fences. Permit fees are found in section
9-1-4 of this title. (Ord. 2006-9-41, 9-7-2006)
9-5-3: FENCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   All Fences: All fences, in all zoning districts, shall be erected so
that the finished side of the fence shall face outward from the property on
which it is erected.
   B.   Business, Town Center, Industrial And Public Zoning Districts: A
minimum six foot (6') high fence with a closed fabric design or compact hedge
shall be erected along the lot line of lots in districts zoned Business, Town
Center, Industrial or Public where such lot lines abut a Residence District so
as to provide effective screening. The owner of such a lot shall be responsible
for the erection and maintenance of the required fence or hedge.
   C.   Multi-Family Zoning Districts:
      1.   A minimum six foot (6') high fence with a closed fabric design or
compact hedge shall be erected along the lot line of improved lots in districts
zoned Multi-Family where such lot lines abut Single-Family Residence Districts.
The owner of such a lot shall be responsible for the erection and maintenance
of the required fence or hedge.
      2.   For the purpose of this subsection, multi-family is as defined in
the Winfield Zoning Ordinance.
      3.   This provision does not apply to lot lines within a planned unit
development since the Winfield Zoning Ordinance contains screening requirements
applicable to such development.
   D.   Swimming Pools: Fences shall be erected around swimming pools as
required in the Winfield Building Code, chapter 1 of this title. (Ord. 2018-12-
39, 12-20-2018)
9-5-3-1: RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS:
   A.   Height Limitations: No fence shall be erected in excess of six feet
(6') along interior or rear lot lines; provided, that the height limitations
contained herein shall not apply to shrubs or hedges on interior lot lines or
rear lot lines except as required by section
9-5-3 of this chapter, and shall not apply to property owned by tax levying
districts, and all fences abutting regulation size tennis courts shall be
exempt from the height limitations of this chapter.
   B.   Location: Except as follows, all permitted fences must be constructed
within one foot (1') of the fence owner's interior or rear lot lines, and all
such fences shall be permanent and not temporary structures. Exceptions are as
follows:
      1.   Patio privacy fences not to exceed six feet (6') in height within
the rear and side building lines.
      2.   A dog enclosure or run not to exceed six feet (6') in height, or
enclose an area greater than twenty percent (20%) of the rear yard may be
constructed in the rear yard, providing it is set back five feet (5') from all
property lines.
      3.   Garden fence enclosing a garden in a rear or side yard, not to
exceed four feet (4').
   C.   Permitted Fences In Residential Districts In Subdivisions On Major
Arterial Highways: Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection 9-5-4E of this
chapter, to allow for some degree of uniformity in perimeter fencing, in
connection with the approval of subdivisions that have two (2) or more lots
that adjoin major arterial highways as defined herein, the President and Board
of Trustees may allow a corner side yard fence to be located closer to the
abutting major arterial highway subject to the following limitations:
      1.   At least fifty percent (50%) of the lots improved with single-family
residences and located within the corporate limits and within three thousand
feet (3,000') of and on the same side of the major arterial highway as the
subdivision, have fences (other than landscape and decorative fences) in the
corner side or rear yards abutting the major arterial highway.
      2.   The developer of the subdivision desires to provide uniform
screening from the traffic and noise caused by that major arterial highway and
one or more of the lots in the subdivision are platted so that the rear lot
line, as defined in the Zoning Ordinance 1 , abuts the major arterial highway
and therefore the desired screening is allowed for that lot.
      3.   The corner side yard fence is located within three feet (3') of the
lot line.
      4.   The corner side yard fence is not located in the vision triangle
formed by drawing a straight line along the property line abutting each
intersecting street a distance of twenty five feet (25') commencing at the
point where the corner side yard lot line and the front yard lot line meet, and
then connecting the termination points of each of those lines to enclose a
triangle.
      5.   The corner side yard fence does not extend into the front yard.
(Ord. 91-10-4, 10-1991)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this Code.
9-5-4: PROHIBITED FENCES:
The following fences are hereby prohibited:
   A.   Wire And Electric Fences:
      1.   Barbed wire, chicken wire (unless used to enclose a rear or side
yard garden), hog wire, rope, cable and electrically charged wire; except, that
barbed wire may be used on top of permitted fences in Industrial Districts and
on fences enclosing property owned by a tax levying district.
      2.   Chain-link fences with barbed ends up.
   B.   Snow Fences: Snow fences, except those erected for the sole purpose of
controlling drifting snow between November 1 and March 31, installed only on
that portion of a lot which faces or abuts a road, street or highway, and which
are in place only between November 1 and March 31.
   C.   Fences Blocking Surface Water Drainage: A fence which is so constructed
as to prevent natural water drainage and/or water runoff.
   D.   Gates Or Fences Across Driveways: No gate or fence is permitted across
a driveway within the front or side yard abutting a street in a Residence
District.
   E.   Fences In Front Yards: Any fence, except a required fence, a decorative
or landscape fence as set forth in sections
9-5-1 and
9-5-3 of this chapter, in a front yard, if the fence would be closer to any
street or roadway than the front building lines established by the building or
residence as located on the lot (see figure A of this section).
   F.   Corner Lot Fences: Any fence on a corner lot which extends closer to
the adjoining street than the front or side line of the existing structure (see
figure A of this section) except for decorative and landscape fences as
permitted in section
9-5-3 of this chapter. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Building
Commissioner, without a public hearing, on application by the property owner,
is authorized to issue variance to allow the following:
      1.   With respect to corner lots in Business Districts (including the
Town Center), a fence on a corner lot to extend closer to the adjoining street
than the front or side line of the existing structure principal building, if
screening from an adjoining use is desirable but not otherwise required by this
chapter, on the condition that the fence extend no closer to the adjoining
street than the line of an existing structure on an adjoining lot, and that the
fence not create an additional vision obstruction for traffic or pedestrians.
      2.   With respect to corner lots in all Residential Districts, if an
existing corner side yard is wider by more than five feet (5') than the corner
side yard width required by the regulations of the Residential Zoning District
in which it is located and the location of one or more mature trees makes it
impossible to place a fence as close to the street abutting the corner side
yard as this chapter would otherwise allow, then a corner side yard fence can
be located closer to the abutting street right-of-way subject to the following
limitations:
         a.   The fence must be at least one foot (1') from, but not within,
said right-of-way.
         b.   No fence shall be located in the vision triangle formed by
drawing a straight line along the property line abutting each intersecting
street a distance of twenty five feet (25') commencing at the point where the
corner side yard lot line and front yard lot line meet, and then connecting the
termination points of each of those lines to enclose a triangle.
         c.   That part of the fence which is located in the corner side yard
cannot exceed four feet (4') in height and must be open weave design so that
the fence is at least fifty percent (50%) open.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/e69e56974fd8eb3967f8b4473ce72c7a644bafb1/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2152.gif]
(Ord. 2018-12-39, 12-20-2018)
9-5-5: NONCONFORMING FENCES:
   A.   Damaged Fences; Restoration And Repair: A fence which does not comply
with this chapter but which is in place on or before the effective date hereof
and which is destroyed by fire or other casualty or act of God or deteriorates
to the extent that the cost of restoration to the condition in which it was
before the occurrence will exceed fifty percent (50%) of the cost of
restoration of the entire fence now, shall not be restored unless said fence
shall conform to all regulations of this chapter. In the event that such damage
or destruction is less than fifty percent (50%) of the cost of restoration of
the fence now, no repairs or reconstruction shall be made unless such
restoration is started within one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of
the partial destruction and is diligently prosecuted to completion.
   B.   Amortization Period: Any fence erected prior to the effective date
hereof which is in violation of any provision of this chapter shall be removed
or brought into compliance with all provisions of this chapter no later than
twenty five (25) years subsequent to the effective date hereof. (Ord. 671, 8-
22-1984)
9-5-6: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with,
or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall,
upon conviction, be fined as provided in section
13-1-3 of this Code for each offense. Each day that a violation is permitted to
exist after notification thereof shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord.
671, 8-22-1984; amd. 1994 Code; per correspondence dated 7-31-2018)
CHAPTER 6
SWIMMING POOLS 1
(Rep. by Ord. 2016-12-28, 12-1-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 9-1-1L of this title.
CHAPTER 7
DEMOLITION
SECTION:
9-7-1: Purpose
9-7-2: Permit Required
9-7-3: Asbestos Abatement Contractors
9-7-4: Standards
9-7-5: Public Notice
9-7-6: Contractor Registration; Bond/Letter Of Credit
9-7-7: Penalty
9-7-1: PURPOSE:
These regulations are provided to regulate the demolition of existing
structures and appurtenances in the village of Winfield to ensure the
protection of the permit holder, workers, and the general public. (Ord. 2006-8-
32, 8-3-2006)
9-7-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   A demolition permit shall be obtained from the village of Winfield
prior to any demolition of any structure or interior load bearing wall of any
structure.
   B.   The following additional regulations shall pertain to demolitions of
habitable residential and commercial buildings exceeding five hundred (500)
square feet in area:
      1.   A hazardous material removal permit shall be required for all
demolitions, alterations, or repairs of a structure which has been determined
to contain asbestos or other hazardous material regulated by the Illinois
department of environmental protection title 35: environmental protection,
subtitle G: waste disposal, chapter I: pollution control board, subchapter c:
hazardous waste operating conditions, part 721 - identification and listing of
hazardous materials, and part 729 prohibited hazardous wastes in land disposal
units. Such permit shall be secured prior to the commencement of demolition.
The village's permit application shall be accompanied by a state of Illinois
notification of demolition and renovation form.
      2.   The permit application shall be accompanied by a phase I
environmental report from an individual or firm licensed by the state of
Illinois department of public health to perform such assessment, noting the
extent of the presence of asbestos or other hazardous materials, if any.
      3.   Before a building or structure can be wrecked, the owner, person or
firm shall notify all utilities having service connections within the building,
such as water, electric, gas, sewer and other connections to disconnect said
services to prevent pollution and hazardous material, such as ignition of
natural gas by construction activities. A permit to demolish will not be issued
until a release is obtained from all utilities, stating that their respective
service connections and appurtenant equipment, such as meters and regulators,
have been removed, sealed, or plugged in a safe manner. In the case of a
property being served by a private well and/or septic field, the permit
applicant shall supply a statement from a plumber licensed in the state of
Illinois that the well and septic field services have been disconnected, and
provide a detailed plan for the use or abandonment/removal of the private
facilities following the demolition of the structure being served.
   C.   The demolition contractor shall comply with all other applicable state,
local or federal laws with respect to demolition activity. (Ord. 2006-8-32, 8-
3-2006)
9-7-3: ASBESTOS ABATEMENT CONTRACTORS:
   A.   Any person or firm engaged in commercial activity of construction,
demolition, alteration or repair of a structure for which has been determined
asbestos containing material is present, must be properly licensed by the state
of Illinois department of public health and registered with the village of
Winfield.
   B.   Any person engaged in commercial activity of asbestos removal shall
comply with the Illinois pollution control board regulations, 35 Illinois
administrative code 228 and as amended. (Ord. 2006-8-32, 8-3-2006)
9-7-4: STANDARDS:
   A.   Toppling Of Walls: When demolition by toppling occurs, such reasonable
measures for dust emission control as it is compatible with the type and
structure shall be utilized, and adequate fall areas shall be determined.
   B.   Dust Control: Before the demolition of any section of wall, floor,
roof, or other structure, adequate wetting procedures to allay the dust shall
be utilized; all debris shall be thoroughly wetted before loading and while
dumping into trucks, other vehicles or containers. Use of a water spray fogging
nozzle is generally preferred. Where buckets are used, the debris shall be
adequately wetted to preclude dust dispersion when buckets are dumped. In the
event particulate matter becomes airborne for a continuous period of ten (10)
minutes, despite the application of water or due to freezing temperatures, the
work of demolition shall cease at once until other adequate dust control
measures can be taken.
   C.   Transport Of Debris: Trucks shall be adequately covered or enclosed to
prevent dust dispersion while in transit to point of disposal.
   D.   Structural Supports; Steel And Wood Beams And Trusts: No structural
members shall be dropped or thrown from any floor but shall be carefully
lowered to ground level by hoists.
   E.   Handling Procedures; Debris: Debris shall not be dropped or thrown from
any floor to any floor below, in buildings three (3) stories or thirty feet
(30') greater in height. Debris shall be transported from the upper floors via
enclosed dusttight chutes or via buckets. Where chutes are used, a water
wetting agent spray shall be employed to saturate the debris before it reaches
the point of discharge from the chute.
   F.   Lot Regulation: Whenever a structure is demolished or removed, the
premises shall be maintained free from all unsafe or hazardous conditions by
the proper regulation of the lot.
   G.   Grading Of Lot: Where a structure has been demolished or removed and a
new building permit has not been issued, the vacant lot shall be filled,
graded, and maintained in conformity to the established elevation of the street
grade at the curb level nearest the point of demolition or excavation. The
permit holder shall take measures to prevent the accumulation of water or
damage to any foundations on the premises or the adjacent property.
   H.   Cleanliness: The permit holder shall be responsible for keeping
demolition debris and mud within the site. All waste materials shall be removed
in a manner which prevents injury or damage to persons, adjoining properties
and rights of way. If debris or mud ends up off of the site, the permit holder
shall be responsible for its removal and proper disposal before the end of each
workday.
   I.   Segregation Of Materials: Demolition materials shall be segregated
according to combustible and noncombustible. The sorting and disposal of debris
in on site special purpose containers is encouraged. The permit holder shall
make certain that proper precautions are undertaken for handling various toxic
chemicals: acids, fuel oils, cleaning fluids, paints, and those materials are
disposed of as prescribed by law.
   J.   Site Protection: A perimeter shall be established around the structure
and appurtenances subject to demolition, in which demolition work will be
contained. The perimeter shall provide adequate room for maneuvering equipment,
short term storage of demolition materials, and take into consideration
adequate fall zones. The perimeter shall be entirely enclosed through the
installation of four foot (4') high orange "snow fencing" to keep unauthorized
parties out of the demolition area. Signs shall be installed warning members of
the public of the dangers of demolition.
   K.   Site Safety: Permit holders shall ensure that all persons performing
demolition work comport their activities consistent with the United States
department of labor occupational safety and health administration standards,
including: 29 CFR 1926, subparts D - occupational health and environmental
controls; E - personal protective equipment and life safety equipment; I -
personal protective equipment, respiratory protection; J - welding and cutting;
L - scaffolds; M - fall protection; T - demolition; and Z - toxic and hazardous
substances.
   L.   Protection Of Adjacent Properties: The permit holder shall at all times
and at his/her own expense preserve and protect the adjoining lot(s), building
(s), or structure(s) from damage or injury. (Ord. 2006-8-32, 8-3-2006)
9-7-5: PUBLIC NOTICE:
The permit holder shall inform all property owners within two hundred fifty
feet (250') of the perimeter of the property subject to the demolition permit
of the pending demolition work at least seven (7) days prior to the
commencement of demolition. Notification shall be by first class mail. (Ord.
2006-8-32, 8-3-2006)
9-7-6: CONTRACTOR REGISTRATION; BOND/LETTER OF CREDIT:
   A.   Any contractual firm performing demolition work under contract shall
comport to the requirements for registration as provided in this title.
   B.   For demolition work being performed by the owner of record without
assistance of a contractor or subcontractor, no demolition permit shall be
issued until:
      1.   The applicant files with the Village of Winfield Building Department
an indemnifying bond issued by a company approved and authorized to issue bonds
by the State of Illinois or letter of credit in a form suitable to the Village
of Winfield in an amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or payable to the
Village of Winfield, for the use to complete demolition work in the event that
the permit holder fails to complete said demolition within one year from the
date of commencement.
      2.   The applicant shows proof of general liability insurance in the
forms of certificate of insurance and a letter from the insured's carrier to
adequately cover claims for damages that could result from performance of
demolition work by the owner of record. The minimum level of general liability
coverage shall be five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) aggregate. (Ord.
2006-8-32, 8-3-2006)
9-7-7: PENALTY:
Any person or firm who shall violate a provision of this chapter, or fail to
comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof shall be fined as
provided in sections
13-1-3 and
13-1-4 of this Code. (Ord. 2019-02-01, 2-7-2019)
CHAPTER 8
BUILDING CONSTRUCTION NUISANCES
SECTION:
9-8-1: Purpose
9-8-2: Applicability
9-8-3: Informing The General Public
9-8-4: Materials And Spoils Storage
9-8-5: Access; Fencing
9-8-6: Site Management Standards
9-8-7: Site Management Deposit
9-8-8: Penalty
9-8-1: PURPOSE:
These regulations are designed to ameliorate the public health, safety and
